questions.text: The parents of a 2-month-old girl are concerned that their child may be at risk for autism because her 18-month-old cousin was recently diagnosed with autism. Which of the following most accurately describes an early sign of autism?
questions.solution:
Absence of a social smile and/or limited eye contact by 6 months of age may be an early sign of autism.

Additional early signs of autism include -

  • absence of babbling, pointing or other gestures by 12 months
  • not using single words by 16 months or 2-word phrases by 24 months
  • stereotypic use of language; lack of make-believe play by 18 months

Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 20th edition, pg-210

choices.text: Hypoxia stimulates pyruvate dehydrogenase by increased 2,3-DPG
Hypoxia stimulates release of all glycolytic enzymes from Band 3 on RBC membrane
Activation of the regulatory enzymes by high pH

questions.text: Within the RBC, hypoxia stimulates glycolysis by which of the following regulating pathways:
questions.solution:
Hypoxia stimulates release of all glycolytic enzymes from Band 3 on the RBC membrane. 2,3-BPG stabilizes the tertiary structure of hemoglobin

  • A low Po2 in peripheral tissues promotes the synthesis of 2,3-bisphosphoglycerate (BPG) in erythrocytes. The hemoglobin tetramer binds one molecule of BPG in the central cavity formed by its four subunits . However, the space between the H helices of the b chains lining the cavity is sufficiently wide to accommodate BPG only when hemoglobin is in the T state. BPG therefore stabilizes deoxygenated (T-state) hemoglobin by forming additional salt bridges that must be broken prior to conversion to the R state.
  • Synthesis of BPG from the glycolytic intermediate 1,3-bisphosphoglycerate is catalyzed by the bifunctional enzyme 2,3-bisphosphoglycerate synthase/2-phosphatase (BPGM). BPG is hydrolyzed to 3-phosphoglycerate by the 2-phosphatase activity of BPGM and to 2-phosphoglycerate by a second enzyme, multiple inositol polyphosphate phosphatase (MIPP). The activities of these enzymes, and hence the level of BPG in erythrocytes, are sensitive to pH.
  • As a consequence, BPG concentration and binding are influenced by, and reinforce the impact of, the Bohr effect on O2 binding and delivery by hemoglobin.

Reference: Harper, 30th edition , p57

questions.text: A 10 year old male, a known case of Thalassemia major is on Blood transfusion therapy every 21 days. His baseline hemoglobin is 8.6 g/dl. His serum ferritin is 1000 ng/dl. What is the most appropriate drug used for chelation therapy for this patient?
questions.solution:
Drug of choice for acute iron overload is desferrioxamine. However, it has to be administered parenterally. It is not effective by oral route.

In beta thalassemia major, iron excess can result due to repeated blood transfusions and massive hemolysis. The chelating agent has to be administered for a long time in this case. Therefore oral Deferiprone is prefered in this case.

EDTA, given intramuscularly, is not used for iron overload.

Reference: Harrison 21st edition page 763

questions.text: Bogorad's syndrome occurs due to injury of the facial nerve at which level?
questions.solution:
Crocodile tears syndrome/Bogorad's syndrome -

Lacrimation during eating occurs due to aberrant regeneration after trauma.

In case of damage to the facial nerve proximal to geniculate ganglion, regenerating fibers for submandibular salivary gland grow in endoneurial sheaths of preganglionic secretomotor fibers supplying the lacrimal gland.

That is why patient lacrimates while eating food.

Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia, Volume - 4, 8th Edition, Page No - 82

questions.text: An increase in the p50 of an oxyhemoglobin curve would result from a decrease in.
questions.solution:
p50 is the level of PO2 at which 50% of hemoglobin is saturated with oxygen. P50 assesses the binding affinity of hemoglobin for oxygen. So if P50 is high, it signifies the decrease in affinity of Hb for oxygen, which is seen in the right-shift of the oxygen-hemoglobin equilibrium curve. A decrease in pH shifts the curve to the right which leads to increase in P50



Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 25th Edition Page 640

questions.text: A 10 days old neonate presents with a large patch of blue-gray pigmentation with irregular shape, unclear edges and normal skin texture involving buttocks and lower back. She is otherwise healthy and has no dysmorphic features. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Congenital dermal melanocytosis (Mongolian spot)

  • Congenital blue-gray macule found over the sacral skin area.
  • Pigmentation initially deepens and then regresses completely by age 7 years

Option A - Blue Nevi

  • Benign skin lesion that is four times more common in children, typically affecting the extremities and face.
  • Small, slightly elevated, and blue-black lesions. However, blue-black papules and nodules that are new or growing must be evaluated to rule out nodular melanoma

Option D - Infantile hemangioma

  • Strawberry, capillary, or cavernous hemangioma. Benign endothelial proliferation that represents the most common tumor in infancy.
  • Most commonly on head and neck areas.
  • Superficial ones presented as bright red-colored plaque. Deep ones present as a soft dermal or subcutaneous nodule with a bluish- purple color.
  • More than 90% of untreated hemangiomas involute, that is, attain maximal regression by 9 years of age. Up to 30% of hemangiomas leave post involution changes including hypopigmentation, scarring, telangiectasia, and fibrofatty tissue.

Reference: Bolognia textbook of dermatology, 4th edition

choices.text: WBC and differential blood cell count

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy who is small for his age has a painful limp and limited hip motion. Radiographs of the pelvis are shown. In addition to managing the problem with the hip, what laboratory studies should be obtained?
questions.solution:
The child has bilateral slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE).

SCFE usually develops in early adolescence, but can occur in younger children with endocrine disorders such as panhypopituitarism and hypothyroidism.

Any child younger than age 10 years or older than age 16 years who has SCFE should be carefully evaluated for an underlying endocrine problem.

Reference: Loder RT, Wittenberg B, DeSilva G: Slipped capital femoral epiphysis associated with endocrine disorders. J Pediatr Orthop 1995;15:349-356./p>

Wells D, King JD, Roe TF, et al: Review of slipped capital femoral epiphysis associated with endocrine disease. J Pediatr Orthop 1993;13:610-614

questions.text: A 60yr old post menopausal woman presents to OPD with DEXA scan reports which showed a score of -2.5. She has a history of Colles fracture 6 months back. She is not a smoker and doesn't take alcohol. Which of the following should be the first line of treatment for her?
questions.solution:
According to the given history, the patient seems to be suffering from osteoporosis.

OSTEOPOROSIS

It is a quantitative defect of bone. It is usually seen in elderly, especially in post - menopausal women. Decrease in estrogen in old age causes decrease in bone mass and density.

It can be primary or secondary -

  • Primary

Seen in post - menopausal women, old age

  • Secondary

Due to other factors (Steroid usage, chronic disuse, Hyperparathyroidism, Rheumatoid Arthritis, Astronaut's weightlessness).

Lab findings are all normal. (Serum Calcium, Parathormone levels, Alkaline Phosphatase, Serum Phosphate)

H/o pathological fractures (Most Common - Vertebral)

Kyphosis

Fish mouth appearance / Codfish appearance seen on X - Ray

DEXA scan (Investigation of choice)



TREATMENT :-

  • Bisphosphonates (Drug of choice, First line) Eg : Zoledronate, Risedronate, Alendronate
  • Denosumab (Monoclonal Antibody that inhibits RANK Ligand)
  • SERMs (Eg : Raloxifene)
  • Teriparatide (Synthetic PTH) : Given in pulsatile doses to stimulate bone formation.
  • Surgical Methods : Done to repair/reconstruct deformed bones. Eg : Kyphoplasty, Vertebroplasty.

Reference: Essential Orthopedics Manish Kumar Varshney, 1st edition page no 64

questions.text: All of the following types of meningitis are associated with increased CSF protein concentration except -
questions.solution:
Option A: A spinal tap yields cloudy or frankly purulent CSF with as many as 90,000 neutrophils per cubic millimeter, increased CSF pressure and increased protein concentration, and markedly reduced glucose content.

Option B: In aseptic (viral) meningitis, there is a lymphocytic pleocytosis, the protein elevation is only moderate, and the glucose content is nearly always normal.

Option C: The CSF may contain few cells but usually has a high concentration of protein. The mucoid-encapsulated yeasts can be visualized in the CSF with special stains or detected indirectly using assays for cryptococcal antigens.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease 10th ed. Pg 1262, 1268

24 hours after the last dose

questions.text: Which of the following is the best time to estimate lithium concentration for the purpose of serum level monitoring?
questions.solution:
Because of the low therapeutic index for Li+, regular determination of serum concentrations is crucial. Concentrations considered to be effective and acceptably safe are between 0.6 and 1.5 mEq/L. The range of 1.0-1.5 mEq/L is favored for treatment of acutely manic patients.

Somewhat lower values (0.6-1.0 mEq/L) are considered adequate and are safer for long-term prophylaxis. Serum concentrations of Li+ have been found to follow a clear dose-effect relationship between 0.4 and 1.0 mEq/L, but with a corresponding dose-dependent rise in polyuria and tremor as indices of adverse effects.

By convention, the serum Li+ concentration is measured from samples obtained 10-12 h after the last oral dose of the day.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman's The Pharmacological Basis of therapeutics 13th /e, p 296

questions.text: Which of the following features of FSGS differentiates it from minimal change disease?
questions.solution:
The clinical signs of FSGS differ from those of minimal change disease in the following respects:

  • there is a higher incidence of hematuria, reduced GFR, and hypertension;
  • proteinuria is more often nonselective;
  • there is poor response to corticosteroid therapy; and
  • there is progression to chronic kidney disease, with at least 50% developing ESRD within 10 years.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease, 10th ed. Pg 915

choices.text: Repeated administration of ephedrine decreases its effect on blood pressure

Increase in pulse pressure is produced by intravenous administration of isoprenaline

questions.text: Which of the following statements correctly describes the phenomenon of vasomotor reversal of Dale?
questions.solution:
Blockade of vasoconstrictor α1 (also α2) receptors reduces peripheral resistance and causes pooling of blood in capacitance vessels → venous return and cardiac output are reduced → fall in BP. Postural reflex is interfered with → marked hypotension occurs on standing → dizziness and syncope. Hypovolemia accentuates the hypotension.

The α blockers abolish the pressor action of Adr (injected i.v. in animals), which then produces only fall in BP due to β2 mediated vasodilatation. This was first demonstrated by Sir HH Dale (1913) and is called vasomotor reversal of Dale.

Pressor and other actions of selective α agonists (phenylephrine) are suppressed.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th/e, p 153

questions.text: A 56 year old farmer presented to the emergency department with a BP of 190/110 mmHg and pulmonary edema suspected to be due to scorpion sting is best managed by which of the following drugs?
questions.solution:
Scorpion stings cause a wide range of symptoms, from severe local reactions to cardiovascular, respiratory and neurological manifestations.

Alpha-receptors play a vital role in the pathogenesis of cardiac failure and pulmonary edema due to scorpion sting.

Prazosin is a selective alpha-1 adrenergic receptor blocker. It dilates veins and arterioles, thereby reducing preload and left ventricular impedance without rise in heart rate and renin secretion. It also inhibits sympathetic outflow in the central nervous system. It enhances insulin secretion, which is inhibited by venom action. It has also been found useful even in cases with hypotension. Thus, its pharmacological properties can antagonize the hemodynamic, hormonal and metabolic effects of scorpion venom action.

Reference: Harrison's Principle of Internal Medicine 20th /e p3329

questions.text: A 28 year old patient was diagnosed with rheumatoid arthritis and was on medications for the same. After 2 years, he developed blurring of vision and was found to have corneal opacity. Which of the following drugs is most likely to cause this?
questions.solution:
Prolonged use of high doses of chloroquine (as needed for rheumatoid arthritis, DLE etc.) may cause loss of vision due to retinal damage.

Corneal deposits may also occur and affect vision, but are reversible on discontinuation.

Sulfasalazine, methotrexate and leflunomide are used in rheumatoid arthritis but do not cause blurring of vision due to corneal opacity.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th /e p880

questions.text: A newborn baby has microcephaly and bilateral club foot. On brain imaging, cerebellar and brainstem hypoplasia, thinning of cerebral cortex and subcortical calcification are seen. On ocular examination, macular scarring and chorioretinal atrophy are seen. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Congenital Zika syndrome -

  • Transmitted in the 1st and 2nd trimesters, not in 3rd
  • Via Hofbauer cells in placenta (placental macrophages), attaches to AXL receptors in the fetal brain
  • Predominantly affects the posterior segment of eye and brain
  • Can cause contractures (arthrogryposis, CTEV), vision and hearing impairment
  • Diagnosis is by isolation of virus from the CSF/blood/urine, confirmation by the plaque neutralization test
  • Can be transmitted through the breastmilk, but breast feeding must be continued as the major damage occurs antenatally

Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 20th edition

choices.text: It arrests cells in G1 phase of cell cycle
It inhibits apoptosis occurring by mitochondrial pathway
Mutations in p53 are associated with cancers

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about p53?
questions.solution:
If DNA repair mechanisms activated by p53 fail to correct the DNA damage, p53 triggers apoptosis by the mitochondrial pathway.

Option A & D - DNA damage activates p53, which arrests cells in the G1 phase of the cell cycle and activates DNA repair mechanisms.

Option C - Mutations in p53 that interfere with its ability to arrest cell cycling or to induce apoptosis are associated with numerous cancers.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease 10th ed. Pg 51

questions.text: Werner syndrome occurs due to defect of which of the following mechanisms of DNA repair -
questions.solution:
Diseases of DNA Damage Repair

  • Defective Nonhomologous End Joining Repair (NHEJ)
    • Severe combined immunodeficiency disease (SCID)
    • Radiation sensitive severe combined immunodeficiency disease (RS-SCID)
  • Defective Homologous Repair (HR)
    • AT-like disorder (AT LD)
    • Nijmegen breakage syndrome (NBS)
    • Bloom syndrome (BS)

    • Rothmund-Thomson syndrome (RTS)

  • Defective DNA Nucleotide Excision Repair (NER)
    • Xeroderma pigmentosum (XP)
    • Cockayne syndrome (CS)
    • Trichothiodystrophy (TT D)
  • Defective DNA Base Excision Repair (BER)

  • Defective DNA Mismatch Repair (MMR)

questions.text: Negative stretch reflex is mediated by -
questions.solution:
Relaxation of the muscle in response to a strong stretch is called inverse stretch reflex. Receptors are Golgi tendon organs (GTO). A stronger stretch imparted on the muscle automatically inhibits the muscle. Therefore, the reflex is also called autogenic inhibition.

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 25th Edition Page 232

questions.text: The vena caval opening lies at which vertebral level in the diaphragm?
questions.solution:
Structures passing through the diaphragm -

There are three large and several small openings in the diaphragm which allow passage to structures from thorax to abdomen or vice versa.

  • Large openings
    • Vena caval opening in the central tendon (T8)
      • IVC
      • Rt phrenic nerve
    • Esophageal opening in the right crus of diaphragm (T10)
      • Esophagus
      • Rt and lt vagus trunks
      • Lt gastric vessels
    • Aortic opening behind the median arcuate ligament (T12)
      • Aorta
      • Thoracic duct
      • Azygos vein
  • Minor openings
    • The lesser aperture of the right crus (lesser and greater splanchnic nerves)
    • The lesser aperture of the left crus (hemiazygos vein, lesser and greater splanchnic nerves)
    • The sympathetic trunk runs posteriorly below the medial lumbocostal arches.
    • Foramen of Morgagni is found in the areolar tissue between the sternal and costal part of the diaphragm (superior epigastric branch of the internal thoracic artery)
    • The medial and lateral lumbocostal arches can contain areolar tissue that, when present, separates the superior and posterior surface of a kidney from the pleura.

Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia, Volume-1, 8th Edition, Page No - 216

choices.text: Glucagon acts only in the liver
5'AMP is an allosteric activator of glycogen phosphorylase

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding glycogen metabolism -
questions.solution:
• Epinephrine acts in muscle and liver both, whereas glucagon acts only in the liver.
  • Epinephrine increases cAMP in the cell leading to increased phosphorylation of the enzyme and increased glycogenolysis.
  • In the liver, the role of glycogen is to provide free glucose for export to maintain the blood concentration of glucose; in muscle, the role of glycogen is to provide a source of glucose-6-phosphate for glycolysis in response to the need for ATP for muscle contraction.
  • In both tissues, the enzyme is activated by phosphorylation catalyzed by phosphorylase kinase, and inactivated by dephosphorylation catalyzed by phosphoprotein phosphatase.
  • Active phosphorylase in both the tissues is allosterically inhibited by ATP and glucose-6-phosphate
  • In the liver, but not in muscle, free glucose is also an inhibitor.
  • Muscle phosphorylase differs from the liver isoenzyme in having a binding site for 5′ AMP , which acts as an allosteric activator of the enzyme.

Reference: Harper 30/e p422

questions.text:
Select the correct statements from the following -
1) The direct Coombs test is used to detect the presence of antibodies that have already attached to the red blood cells.
2)The indirect Coombs test is used to detect the presence of antibodies in the serum that can attach to red blood cells in the future.
3)The direct Coombs test is useful in diagnosing haemolytic anemia caused by Rh incompatibility.
4)The indirect Coombs test is useful in screening for potential transfusion reactions.
questions.solution:
The Coombs test, also known as the antiglobulin test, is used to detect the presence of antibodies that have already attached to the red blood cells (direct Coombs test) or antibodies in the serum that can attach to red blood cells in the future (indirect Coombs test).

The direct Coombs test is useful in diagnosing hemolytic anemia caused by Rh incompatibility.

The indirect Coombs test is useful in screening for potential transfusion reactions.

Reference: Guyton and Hall, Textbook of Medical Physiology, 14th edition Pg. 471-475

questions.text: A female with BMI>30 presented to the dermatology OPD with lesions as shown in the image. Which of the following conditions is associated with the condition?
questions.solution:
The image is showing hyperpigmented velvety lesions present over the neck suggestive of acanthosis nigricans.

Etiology

  • Obesity
  • Drugs (Protease inhibitors, nicotinic acid)
  • Endocrine cause (PCOD - HAIRAN syndrome-Hyperandrogenism, Insulin resistance, Acanthosis nigricans)
  • Malignancy (Gastric adenocarcinoma)

Mechanism:

  • Increased circulating insulin
  • IGF activation
  • Keratinocytes, dermal fibroblast proliferation

Reference - Bolognia textbook of dermatology, 4th edition

choices.text: It is present in most somatic tissues.
It removes nucleotides from the ends of chromosomes.
Only germ cells have sufficient telomerase to stabilize telomere length completely.
It is inactivated in immortalized cancer cells.

questions.text: What is true about telomerase?
questions.solution:
Telomere length is maintained by nucleotide addition mediated by an enzyme called telomerase. Germ cells and stem cells both contain telomerase, but only germ cells have sufficient levels of the enzyme to stabilize telomere length completely.

Option A: Telomerase is expressed in germ cells and is present at low levels in stem cells, but it is absent in most somatic tissues.

Option B: Telomerase is a specialized RNA-protein complex that uses its own RNA as a template for adding nucleotides to the ends of chromosomes.

Option D: In immortalized cancer cells, telomerase is usually reactivated and telomere length is stabilized, allowing the cells to proliferate indefinitely.



Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease 10th ed. Pg 67-68

questions.text: Which of the following teratogenic drugs is associated with deafness in a newborn baby?
questions.solution:
Isotretinoin can cause microtia or anotia. These defects are frequently associated with agenesis or stenosis of the external ear canal and may lead to deafness. Facial defects include cleft palate and maldevelopment of the facial bones and cranium. Cardiac anomalies include conotruncal or outflow tract defects. Hydrocephalus is the most common central nervous system defect. Thymic abnormalities include aplasia, hypoplasia or malposition.

Option B - Chloroquine is not teratogenic

Option C - Features of Fetal Alcohol Syndrome -

  • Behavior disturbances
  • Brain defects
  • Cardiac defects
  • Spinal defects
  • Craniofacial anomalies

Option D - Teratogenic effects of warfarin

  • First trimester → Hypoplastic nasal bridge, chondrodysplasia
  • Second trimester → CNS malformations
  • Third trimester → Risk of bleeding, Discontinue the use one month before delivery.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th /e p954

choices.text: Mutation resulting in altered target site for antibiotics

questions.text: Following phenomenon is responsible for antibiotic resistance in bacteria due to slime formation -
questions.solution:
Slime is amorphous, viscid colloidal material that is secreted extracellularly by some bacteria (Staph epidermidis)

The slime remains around the bacteria and provides a matrix in which biofilm formation can take place.

In biofilm formation the bacterial colony is spread very thinly (300 -400 nm thick), for eg formation of biofilm on catheters and prosthetic devices.

The biofilm formation in the slime provides antibiotic resistance by restricting access of drugs to the bacterium

Reference: Greenwood medical microbiology 16th ed . 38, 86

questions.text: Which amongst the following is the topical immunomodulator used for the treatment of perianal warts?
questions.solution:
Drugs used for viral warts (condyloma acuminata) are -

  • Imiquimod: It is an immune response modifier, useful in the treatment of external genital and peri-anal warts topically.

Mechanism of action against these HPV-induced lesions is unknown. 5% cream is applied 3 times weekly and washed off 6- 10 hours after each application. Recurrences appear to be less common than with ablative therapies. Local skin reactions and pigmentary skin lesions are the important side effects.

  • Resiquimod is another immunomodulator, which is used topically for HSV.
  • Podophyllin acts by inhibiting the polymerization of tubulin monomers in the mitotic spindle.
  • Interferons may be used intralesionally for condyloma acuminata.
  • Acyclovir is used for HSV-1, HSV-2 and varicella zoster virus. It is not useful for CMV infections

Reference: Goodman & Gilman's The Pharmacological Basis of therapeutics 13th/e p1285

questions.text: Gram positive bacteria that produces swarming growth on culture media is -
questions.solution:
Swarming growth is due to motility of bacteria. In the culture medium, discrete colonies are seen but thereafter actively motile cells spread on the surface of the plate in successive waves to form a thin filmy layer in concentric circles.



Gram positive organisms with swarming growth -

  • Clostridium tetani
  • Bacillus cereus

Gram negative organisms with swarming growth -

  • Proteus mirabilis / P. vulgaris.

Reference: Ananthanarayan 9th 287

questions.text: The characteristic skin finding of juvenile dermatomyositis is -
questions.solution:
Diagnostic criteria for cutaneous dermatomyositis:

  • Presence of two major criteria or one major and two minor criteria

AND

  • Skin biopsy changes consistent with cutaneous dermatomyositis

MAJOR CRITERIA

  • Heliotrope sign (heliotrope rash is a reddish purple rash on or around the eyelids)
  • Gottron papules (small purple or red flat papules on extensor surfaces, particularly the elbows and joints of the hand)
  • Gottron sign (symmetric confluent macular violaceous erythema with or without edema at the dorsal aspect of the IP/MCP joints, olecranon processes, patellae, and medial malleoli)

MINOR CRITERIA

  • Macular violaceous erythema involving (each area counts as a minor criterion)
  • Malar eminences of face, forehead or chin
  • V area of neck or upper chest (V sign)
  • Posterior neck or posterior shoulders (shawl sign)
  • Extensor surfaces of arms or forearms
  • Linear streaking overlying extensor tendons of dorsal hands
  • Periungual skin
  • Lateral thighs or hips (Holster sign)
  • Medial malleoli
  • Nail fold capillary telangiectasia, hemorrhage-infarct
  • Poikiloderma
  • Mechanic's hands
  • Cutaneous calcinosis
  • Cutaneous ulcers

Malar rash and photosensitivity are features of SLE

Nail bed capillary changes are features of Systemic Sclerosis

Reference: Bolognia textbook of dermatology, 4th edition

questions.text: Following trauma inoculation, a man presents with the following lesion due to lymphatic spread. Which organism is most likely to be responsible?
questions.solution:
Sporotrichosis (Rose gardener's disease/ rose thorn disease)

Causative agent: Sporothrix schenckii

It is dimorphic fungus

Histopathology shows 'Asteroid bodies

There are 3 types -

  • Cutaneous
    • Nodule with ulceration
    • Itraconazole
  • Lymphatic
    • Linear nodule with satellite lesions are seen (multiple nodules are seen along lymphatics)
    • Saturated solution of Potassium iodide
    • Itraconazole
  • Systemic
    • Inhalation of fungal spores lead to lung upper lobe involvement
    • Amphotericin B

Option C - Madura foot also known as Mycetoma, an uncommon chronic infection of skin and subcutaneous tissues in tropical countries is caused by true fungi (eumycetoma) or by filamentous bacteria (actinomycetoma).



It is characterized by the triad of

  • Painless firm mass
  • Multiple discharging sinus
  • Purulent discharge containing grains

Most common site is the foot (trauma prone area).

Option D - Chromoblastomycosis (Verrucous dermatitis)

Causative agent: Pigmented fungi (Dematiaceous fungi)

  • Fonsecaea pedrosoi
  • Phialophora verrucosa



Clinical feature : Rough warty, cauliflower like lesions over exposed (trauma prone) sites.

Most commonly on foot 

Histopathology shows medlar / sclerotic bodies/ copper penny bodies

Treatment: Itraconazole

Reference: IADVL textbook of dermatology, 4th edition

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy has had pain in the right shoulder for the past 3 months. He denies any history of trauma and has no constitutional symptoms. Examination reveals a large firm mass in the proximal arm. The radiograph and biopsy specimens are shown below. The management of this patient consists of -
questions.solution:
The patient has an aneurysmal bone cyst.

Multiple blood filled sinusoids, with irregular margins, in the metaphysis just abutting the physics, with well defined septae in between.

On biopsy, vascular lakes, multinucleated giant cells, reactive bone, fibrovascular tissue, and an absence of atypical cells or numerous mitoses are seen.

Aneurysmal bone cysts will typically continue to grow and cause further bone destruction; therefore, observation is not recommended.

Steroid injections are not effective. A thorough curettage of the cyst lining and bone grafting are required. Wide resection and chemotherapy are reserved for more aggressive tumors. There is no evidence of infection radiographically or histologically.

Telangiectatic osteosarcoma should also be considered in the differential diagnosis; therefore, biopsy is an important part of the work-up.

Reference: Wold LA, et atlas of Orthopedic Pathology. Philadelphia, PA, WB Saunders, 1990, pp 232-233.

Simon M, et al: Surgery for Bone and Soft Tissue Tumors. Philadelphia, PA, Lippincott Raven, 1998, pp 194-196

questions.text: A 5-yr old child develops fever and nausea. His parents complain of decrease in urine output and cola-coloured urine. He has a past history of sore throat 1 week back. Urine analysis shows grade 1 proteinuria as well as many dysmorphic RBCs. Serum C3 complement levels are reduced. Renal biopsy is advised. On immunofluorescence microscopy of the same, granular IgG and C3 deposits are seen in the mesangium and along the GBM. Electron microscopy shows subepithelial humps. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the typical case of acute proliferative glomerulonephritis, a young child abruptly develops malaise, fever, nausea, oliguria, and hematuria (smoky or cola-colored urine) 1 to 2 weeks after recovery from a sore throat. The patients have dysmorphic red cells or red cell casts in the urine, mild proteinuria (usually less than1 g/day), periorbital edema, and mild to moderate hypertension. Important laboratory findings include elevations of antistreptococcal antibody titers and a decline in the serum concentration of C3 and other components of the complement cascade.

By immunofluorescence microscopy, there are granular deposits of IgG and C3, and sometimes IgM in the mesangium and along the GBM.

The characteristic electron microscopic findings are discrete, amorphous, electron-dense deposits on the epithelial side of the membrane, often having the appearance of 'humps', presumably representing the antigen-antibody complexes at the subepithelial cell surface.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease, 10th ed. Pg 909

questions.text: A 54 year old male patient who was diagnosed with COPD was on Ipratropium bromide by nebulizer. After some weeks of taking the same he observed worsening of symptoms. You suspect that it could be due to Paradoxical Bronchoconstriction. FWhich of the following is least likely to cause this phenomenon?
questions.solution:
Reports of paradoxical bronchoconstriction with ipratropium bromide, particularly when given by nebulizer, were largely explained as effects of the hypotonic nebulizer solution and by antibacterial additives, such as benzalkonium chloride and EDTA.

This problem has not been described with tiotropium bromide or other LAMAs. Occasionally, bronchoconstriction may occur with ipratropium bromide given by MDI. It is possible that this is due to blockade of prejunctional M2 receptors on airway cholinergic nerves that normally inhibit ACh release.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman's The Pharmacological Basis of therapeutics 13th/e p736

choices.text: Anti-HBs antibodies aren't produced in cases progressing to chronic liver diseases
Risk of chronic infection is lowest in infants exposed postnatally
Individuals acquiring HBV at birth and subsequently developing chronic hepatitis are at greatest risk of developing HCC
Persistence of HBeAg indicates continued viral replication

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding serology of HBsAg positive patients?
questions.solution:
The risk of chronic infection is inversely related to age and is greatest (approximately 90%) in infants who are exposed to the virus through transmission from their mothers at the time of birth.

Option A: anti-HBs antibodies are not produced in cases that progress to chronic liver disease, which is also associated with variable persistent elevations of serum transaminases in most (but not all) cases.

Option C: Individuals who acquire HBV at birth and who subsequently develop chronic hepatitis are also at greatest risk of developing hepatocellular carcinoma.

Option D: Persistence of HBeAg is an important indicator of continued virus replication, infectivity, and probable progression to chronic hepatitis.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease, 10th ed. Pg 833

questions.text: Which of the following oral anti-diabetic drugs is associated with increased risk of fractures in a female with osteoporosis?
questions.solution:
Thiazolidinediones

Troglitazone, pioglitazone and rosiglitazone are the drugs in this group that act as agonists of a nuclear receptor; peroxisome proliferator activated receptor gamma (PPARγ). It regulates the transcription of genes involved in glucose and lipid metabolism. Important genes that are up regulated by PPAR-γ are:

  • Adiponectin
  • Fatty acid transport protein
  • Insulin receptor substrate
  • GLUT - 4

These drugs are used to reverse insulin resistance in type II DM. These drugs also tend to increase HDL.

Troglitazone was withdrawn due to serious hepatotoxicity and monitoring of hepatic function is recommended for other glitazones also.

Glitazones have been reported to cause weight gain, edema and plasma volume expansion. Therefore, these should be avoided in CHF patients. (NYHA class III and IV).

Rosiglitazone increases total and LDL cholesterol as well as HDL-cholesterol whereas pioglitazone increases HDL-cholesterol without affecting total and LDL-cholesterol. So, pioglitazone is the preferred agent from this group.

There were concerns of Pioglitazone to be associated with increased risk of bladder cancer on long term use. However, long term studies failed to establish this fact.

Both of these drugs can cause - weight gain, edema, new onset or worsening of macular edema, increase in fracture risk in women, anemia

Reference: Goodman & Gilman's The Pharmacological Basis of therapeutics 13th/e p877

questions.text: A 4-day old infant presents with decreased oral intake and activity. Birth history is unremarkable and he was discharged home on day 2 of his life. On examination, the child is cold, mottled, with decreased pulses. No murmurs are heard on auscultation. Which is the most likely congenital heart defect?
questions.solution:
This infant is in cardiac shock and is presenting due to closure of the ductus arteriosus, which supports the systemic output. Most infants with hypoplastic left heart complex are acutely ill, with signs of congestive heart failure within the first days or weeks after birth.

There are signs and symptoms of severe right-sided and left-sided heart failure: cyanosis of varying degree, and often a characteristic grayish pallor and poor peripheral pulses, which contrast with hyperdynamic cardiac pulsations. Murmurs are not prominent, but a short soft mid-systolic murmur and mid-diastolic rumble may be present. The second heart sound is single, heard loudest at the upper left sternal border, and is accentuated until clinical deterioration with gross right heart failure is advanced.

Retrograde blood flow in the arch of aorta and the ascending aorta on giving O2 is diagnostic.

Definitive management is surgical.

Option A - has a pulmonary ejection systolic murmur and presents with characteristic cyanotic spells.

Option B - parallel pulmonary and systemic circulatory circuits, can not survive without coexistent ASD/PFO/VSD/PDA

Option D - acyanotic, has a pansystolic murmur, CHF occurs at 6-8 weeks of age

Reference: Park's Pediatric cardiology, 6th ed., pg. 258

questions.text: BRAF inhibitors are used in which of the following?
questions.solution:
BRAF inhibitors vemurafenib, dabrafenib and encorafenib are used in the treatment of patients with BRAF-mutant cancers. They selectively target BRAF kinase and thus interfere with the mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK) signaling pathway that regulates the proliferation and survival of carcinoma cells. In addition to their molecularly targeted activity, BRAF inhibitors also have immunomodulatory effects. The MAPK pathway is also involved in T-cell receptor signaling.

Clinical studies have shown that the effectiveness of BRAF inhibitors (for reasons that remain to be determined) vary widely depending on histologic subtype -

  • hairy cell leukemias with BRAF mutations typically show sustained responses
  • melanomas respond transiently
  • colon carcinomas respond little, if at all, emphasizing the value of morphologic diagnosis.


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th ed. Pg 334, 335

questions.text: A 50 year old female presented to an oncologist with a breast lump. On examination and investigations, breast cancer was diagnosed. Echocardiography of the patient shows an ejection fraction of 25%. Which of the following drugs will you avoid in this patient?
questions.solution:
Anthracycline antibiotics act by inhibiting topoisomerase II. Doxorubicin and daunorubicin are primarily used in acute leukemias whereas idarubicin and epirubicin display broader activity against solid tumors (breast carcinoma, Osteosarcoma, Ewing's sarcoma and soft tissue sarcoma).

These agents also generate semiquinone free radicals that are responsible for cardiotoxicity (manifested in the form of dilated cardiomyopathy and congestive heart failure).

This adverse effect can be reduced by using a-tocopherol and dexrazoxane (a free radical scavenger). Liposomal forms of these drugs have decreased cardiac toxicity.

Dilated cardiomyopathy is cumulative, dose-dependent and may present even after discontinuation of the anthracyclines. Earliest morphological feature is swelling of the endoplasmic reticulum. It is followed by loss of cardiomyocytes (myofibrillar dropout). Symptoms are similar to CHF including exertional dyspnea, orthopnea and peripheral edema.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th/e p927

questions.text: Which of the following antigenic determinants of an immunoglobulin molecule is class specific?
questions.solution:
The basic immunoglobulin molecule is composed of two heavy(H)chains and two light(L)chains. They are connected by disulfide bonds.

  • Light chains consist of either two Kappa chains or two lambda chains.
  • Heavy chain belong to five classes ( Ig A, Ig G, Ig M, Ig D, Ig E)

It is the composition of the H chain that determines the class of immunoglobulin.

It is also important to know that it is the constant portion of the heavy chain, and not the variable region, that determines the class of the antibody.

Reference: Ananthanarayan 9th 80

questions.text: Which of the following is the drug of choice for legionnaire's pneumonia?
questions.solution:
Uses of Azithromycin -

Because of higher efficacy, better gastric tolerance and convenient once a day dosing, azithromycin is now preferred over erythromycin as first choice drug for infections such as -

  • Legionnaires' pneumonia: 500 mg OD oral/i.v. for 2 weeks. Erythromycin or a FQ are the alternatives.
  • Chlamydia trachomatis: nonspecific urethritis and genital infections in both men and women -1 g single dose is curative, while 3 weekly doses are required for lymphogranuloma venereum . It is also the drug of choice for chlamydial pneumonia and is being preferred over tetracycline for trachoma in the eye.
  • Donovanosis caused by Calymmatobacterium granulomatis: 500 mg OD for 7 days or 1.0 g weekly for 4 weeks is as effective as doxycycline.
  • Chancroid and PPNG urethritis: single 1.0 g dose is highly curative; may be combined with ceftriaxone

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th/e p804

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of a superantigen?
questions.solution:
Examples of superantigens -

  • Staphylococcal toxic shock syndrome toxin
  • Certain nonhuman retroviral proteins
  • Staphylococcal enterotoxins
  • Yersinia pseudotuberculosis
  • Staphylococcal exfoliative (erythrogenic) toxin
  • Streptococcal pyrogenic exotoxin
  • Mycoplasma arthritis
  • Streptococcal toxic shock syndrome toxin
  • Mouse mammary tumor virus

Reference: Greenwood 16"/e p. 92

questions.text: Which of the following is the most dependent part of the pelvic cavity in supine position?
questions.solution:
1. Hepatorenal space (Morrison's pouch) is of considerable importance as it is the most dependent (lowest) part of the abdominal cavity proper when the body is supine. Fluids tend to collect here. This is the commonest site of a subphrenic abscess, which may be caused by spread of infection from the gallbladder, the appendix, or other organs in the region.
  2. Rectouterine Pouch (Pouch of Douglas): This is the most dependent part of the peritoneal cavity when the body is in the upright position.In the supine position, it is the most dependent part of the pelvic cavity.

Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia, Volume - 2, 8th Edition, Page No - 285, 286

questions.text: In which of the following steps of glycolysis energy is released?
questions.solution:
• Steps releasing ATP at the level of substrate (substrate level phosphorylation)
    • 1, 3 Bisphosphoglycerate to 3 Phosphoglycerate (1, 3 Bisphosphoglycerate Kinase)
    • Phosphoenolpyruvate to Pyruvate. (Pyruvate Kinase)
    • Succinyl CoA to Succinate (Succinate Thiokinase)

Reference: Harper 30/e p170,172

questions.text: Cyanosis is unlikely to be seen with -
questions.solution:
CO poisoning produces anemic hypoxia which is severely harmful. Cyanosis usually occurs only when the quantity of reduced hemoglobin is about 5 g/dL to 7 g/dL. But, in anemic hypoxia, the hemoglobin content itself is less. So, cyanosis cannot occur in anemia.

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 25th Edition Page 651

questions.text: Vitamin K dependent gamma carboxylation of which of the following proteins is required for activation?
questions.solution:
The proteins that are gamma carboxylated by Vitamin K are:

  • Factor II (Prothrombin)
  • Factor VII (Proconvertin or Serum Prothrombin conversion Accelerator, SPCA)
  • Factor IX (Antihemophilic factor or Christmas factor)
  • Factor X (Stuart Prower factor)
  • Protein C, Protein S
  • Osteocalcin, Nephrocalcin
  • Product of gene gas6

Reference: Harper 30/ e , page 717

choices.text: Dartos muscle, external spermatic fascia, cremasteric fascia, internal spermatic fascia
External spermatic fascia, dartos muscle, cremasteric fascia, internal spermatic fascia
Cremasteric fascia, external spermatic fascia, dartos muscle, internal spermatic fascia
External spermatic fascia, cremasteric fascia, internal spermatic fascia, dartos muscle

questions.text: What is the correct arrangement of layers of scrotum from outside inwards?
questions.solution:
Layers of the scrotum:

The scrotum is made up of the following layers from outside inwards

  • Skin, continuation of abdominal skin.
  • Dartos muscle which replaces the superficial fascia. The dartos muscle is prolonged into a median vertical septum between the two halves of the scrotum.
  • The external spermatic fascia from external oblique muscle.
  • The cremasteric(Greek to hang) muscle and fascia from internal oblique muscle.
  • The internal spermatic fascia from fascia transversalis.

Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia, Volume – 2, 8th Edition, Page No – 260

choices.text: Fried cooking items have high content of Trans Fatty Acid
Increased TFA in diet leads to decreased essential fatty acid in the body
Partial hydrogenation decreases Trans Fatty Acid levels

questions.text: All of the following are true about trans fatty acids except -
questions.solution:
Trans fatty acids(TFA)

  • Exacerbate essential fatty acid deficiency by competing for essential fatty acid, so Increase Trans fatty acid in diet leads to decrease Essential fatty acid  in human body
  • Present in dairy products and partially hydrogenated  edible oils
  • They are used in food industry to improve the shelf life
  • Trans fatty acids are present in high amounts in processed foods, fast foods and bakery items
  • Partial hydrogenation of fats increases TFA levels
  • Consumption of trans fatty acid for long-terms may raise the risk factor for cardiovascular diseases like Atherosclerosis, Coronary Artery disease and Diabetes Mellitus

Reference: Harper 30/ e , page 241,242

questions.text: A healthy 20-year-old man deprived of water for several days has an arterial pressure of 118/78 mmHg and a plasma concentration of ADH 5 times above normal. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for the increase in ADH concentration?
questions.solution:
Due to dehydration there will be a rise in plasma osmolality which stimulates the secretion of antidiuretic hormone(ADH) and decreases the frequency of urination. 

Water deprivation ->↑ Plasma osmolality -> Stimulate osmoreceptors in the anterior hypothalamus -> ↑ Release of ADH from posterior pituitary -> ↑ Water permeability of late distal tubule and collecting duct -> ↑ Water reabsorption -> ↑ Urine osmolality -> ↓ Urine volume

Reference: Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology, 25th Edition Page 303

questions.text: A patient presented with the following lesions. Likely diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Segmental vitiligo patients are more common in the pediatric age group. It does not cross the midline. It is stable in nature. It does not respond to medical management.

Option B- Hypomelanosis of Ito

Occur in blaschkoid pattern, linear white streaks, Lesions presents since birth

Option C - Nevus of Ito

Blue coloured macules in the acromioclavicular area

Nevus of Ota

Blue coloured macules in V1, V2 area(around eyes)

Option D - Becker's nevus

Appears around puberty, dark brown macules with hypertrichosis over the dark brown macules.

Reference: Bolognia textbook of dermatology, 4th edition

questions.text: Which of the following is not a branch of the external carotid artery?
questions.solution:
Branches of the external carotid artery:

  • Anterior
    • Superior thyroid 
    • Lingual 
    • Facial
  • Posterior
    • Occipital
    • Posterior auricular
  • Medial
    • Ascending pharyngeal
  • Terminal
    • Maxillary
    • Superficial temporal

Inferior thyroid artery is a branch of the thyrocervical trunk.

Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia, Volume – 3, 8th Edition, Page No – 110

questions.text: A newborn has abdominal distention on day 2 of life. The baby has not passed meconium till now. There is no appreciable anal orifice. What is the next best step in the management of this baby?
questions.solution:
The child in the question is suspected to have an imperforate anus. 

The invertogram or upside-down x-ray is of little value, but a prone cross-table lateral plain x-ray at 24 hours of life(to allow time for bowel distention from swallowed air) with a radiopaque marker on the perineum can demonstrate a low lesion by showing the renal gas bubble <1 cm from the perineal skin.

Reference: Nelson textbook of Pediatrics, 20th ed., pg. 1896

choices.text: Most fibers decussate at the lower end of medulla oblongata
It arises from motor and sensory areas of the cerebral cortex
It ends at anterior horn cells of spinal cord
Lesion at the level of pons produces paralysis on the ipsilateral side

questions.text: Regarding corticospinal tract, all of the following are true, except -
questions.solution:
Pyramidal/corticospinal tracts

  • The pyramidal or corticospinal tract consists of two parts:
    • Lateral corticospinal tract, which lies in the lateral funiculus.
    • Anterior corticospinal tract, which lies in the anterior funiculus.
  • The pyramidal or corticospinal tract is formed by the axons of pyramidal cells predominantly lying in the motor area of cerebral cortex. There is some contribution to it from the axon of cells in pre motor and sensory areas. 
  • From here, the fibers course through the posterior limb of the internal capsule, midbrain, pons and medulla oblongata. 
  • At the lower level of medulla oblongata, 80% of fibers cross to the opposite side. This is known as pyramidal decussation. 
  • The fibers that have crossed enter the lateral column of white matter of the spinal cord. It descends as a lateral corticospinal tract. 
  • Most of these fibers terminate by synapsing through the internuncial neurons at the anterior horn cells.
  • The 15% of fibers that do not cross enter the anterior white column of the spinal cord. It forms the anterior corticospinal tract. The fibers of this tract also cross at appropriate levels to reach grey matter of the opposite half of the spinal cord and synapse with internuncial neurons similar to those of the lateral corticospinal tract.
  • Only 5% corticospinal fibers supply muscles of the same side, chiefly the neck muscles. Thus, neck muscles have bilateral controls.

Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia, Volume – 4, 8th Edition, Page No – 41

questions.text: A 1.5 year old male child bought to you with complaints of fever, cough and cold for 2 days. He also has had a rash for the last 1 day, starting from the face, now on the chest, as follows. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Measles is a serious infection characterized by high fever, an enanthem, cough, coryza, conjunctivitis and a prominent exanthem.

The rash begins on the forehead(around the hairline), behind the ears and on the upper neck as a red maculopapular eruption. It then spreads downward to the torso and extremities, reaching the palms and soles in up to 50% of cases. The exanthem frequently becomes confluent on the face and upper trunk.

Reference: Nelson textbook of Pediatrics, 20th ed., pg. 1544

questions.text: Which of the following antifungal drugs possesses additional anti-inflammatory and antipruritic activity?
questions.solution:
The imidazole derivatives oxiconazole, sulconazole and sertaconazole are used for the topical treatment of infections caused by the common pathogenic dermatophytes. Oxiconazole nitrate is available as a 1% cream and lotion; sulconazole nitrate is supplied as a 1% solution or cream.

Sertaconazole has additional properties of being anti-inflammatory and antipruritic. It is marketed as a 2% strength cream for tinea pedis.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s The Pharmacological Basis of therapeutics 13th/e p1091

questions.text: A 13 year old child has had a sore throat for the last 3 days. He has a fever and also complains of fatigue and loss of appetite for those 3 days. Which medium is used for culture of the throat swab?
questions.solution:
The most common bacterial cause of sore throat in children is Streptococcus pyogenes. The culture medium of choice  for diagnosis is sheep blood agar.

Option A - LJ medium - is used for Mycobacterium tuberculosis

Option C - Nutrient agar - non specific agar

Option D - MacConkey agar - used for checking lactose fermentation

Reference: Ananthanarayan 9th edition, page 213

questions.text: A child and his brother visited your OPD with a history of nausea, vomiting and diarrhea for the last 3 hrs. On questioning, it is found that they both had eaten fried rice from a food stall a few hours ago. What is the likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Important organisms causing food poisoning -

  • IP(incubation period) - 1-6 hrs
    • Staphylococcus(ham, eggs, pastries)
    • Bacillus(fried rice)
  • IP - 8-16 hrs
    • Clostridium perfringens(poultry, beef)
  • IP > 16 hrs
    • Vibrio(shellfish)
    • ETEC(salad)
    • EHEC(bloody diarrhea; ground beef)
    • Salmonella(inflammatory diarrhea; beef, poultry)
    • Shigella(dysentery; potato, salad)
    • C. jejuni(inflammatory diarrhea; milk, poultry)
    • C. botulinum(canned foods; can occur within a few hours of ingestion if the toxin dose is high)

Reference: Ananthanarayan 9th edition, page 334

questions.text: Posterior ciliary artery is a branch of
questions.solution:
BLOOD SUPPLY OF EYE

Reference: A.K. Khurana Anatomy 4th edition pg.12

choices.text: Antrum is most preferred site for biopsy
It is associated with increased risk of lymphoma
Increased expression of IL-10 is associated with pangastritis
Cag-A expressing strains are associated with increased risk of cancer

questions.text: A 40-yr old woman complains of chronic intermittent epigastric pain which is accompanied by episodes of nausea and vomiting. On endoscopy, erosions are noted. An image from gastric biopsy stained with Warthin-Starry Silver stain is shown below. Which of the following is not true regarding this condition?
questions.solution:
Spiral-shaped H. pylori are highlighted in this image showing a section stained with Warthin-Starry silver stain. Organisms are abundant within surface mucus. Genetic polymorphisms that lead to increased expression of the proinflammatory cytokines tumor necrosis factor(TNF) and interleukin(IL)-1β or decreased expression of the anti-inflammatory cytokine IL-10 seem to be associated with development of pangastritis, atrophy, intestinal metaplasia and gastric cancer.

Option A: The antrum is the preferred biopsy site for evaluation of H.pylori gastritis because it is most commonly infected.

Option B: Thus, chronic H.pylori gastritis is associated with increased risk of both gastric adenocarcinoma and lymphoma.

Option D: The CagA gene is present in 50% of H.pylori isolates overall but in 90% of H.pylori isolates in populations with an increased prevalence of gastric cancer. This may, in part, be because CagA-expressing strains colonize the gastric body and induce proinflammatory cytokine secretion, atrophy and intestinal metaplasia more effectively than CagA-negative H. pylori.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease, 10th ed. Pg 767

questions.text: A 40 year old female patient diagnosed with Hyperthyroidism was put on thioamide group of antithyroid drugs. Which of the following side effects is least likely to occur to this patient?
questions.solution:
Thioamides include drugs like methimazole, carbimazole and propylthiouracil.

Agranulocytosis and aplastic anemia is a serious side effect of all of these drugs but it is seen rarely.

Propylthiouracil is associated with hepatotoxicity.

All the 3 drugs are teratogenic. Least teratogenic is propylthiouracil.

Hypothyroidism and goiter can occur due to overtreatment, but this is reversible on stopping the drug.

G.i. intolerance, skin rashes and joint pain. Liver damage can occur, especially with propylthiouracil. Loss or graying of hair, loss of taste and fever are infrequent.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th/e p275

questions.text: The causative organism in Maduromycosis is -
questions.solution:
Mycetoma can be caused by both fungus and bacteria.

  • Actinomycetoma
    • Caused by bacteria:
      • Nocardia
      • Actinomadura
      • Streptomyces
      • Actinomyces
    • Grains are thin
    • Granules are white to yellow
  • Eumycetoma
    • Caused by fungus:
      • Madurella mycetomatis
      • Pseudo-allescheria boydii
      • Phialophora
  • Grains are broad and show septae and chlamydospores
  • Granules are black

Reference: Ananthanarayan 9 le p. 393, 608

questions.text: A 10 year old complains of headache. His best corrected visual acuity in the right eye is 6/36 and in the left eye is 6/6. Retinoscopy shows +5D in the right eye and +1D in the left eye. All other ocular examinations are normal. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Vision in Right eye is 6/36 but the ocular examination is normal. Thus there is no organic cause for decreased vision.

It is due to Anisometric Amblyopia.

Anisometropic amblyopia is caused by a difference in refractive error between the eyes and may result from a difference of as little as 1 dioptre. The more ametropic eye receives a blurred image, in a mild form of visual deprivation. It is frequently associated with microstrabismus and may co-exist with strabismic amblyopia.

Reference: Kanski clinical Ophthalmology 9th edition Pg no.708

questions.text: A 65 year old male patient with a past history of myocardial infarction with hypercholesterolemia was prescribed rosuvastatin. Which of the following drugs should be avoided in this patient while on rosuvastatin?
questions.solution:
All statins are remarkably well tolerated; overall incidence of side effects not differing from placebo.

Notable side effects are:

  • Gastrointestinal complaints and headaches are usually mild. 
  • Rashes and sleep disturbances are uncommon.
  • Rise in serum transaminase can occur, but liver damage is infrequent. Monitoring of liver function is recommended.
  • Muscle aches are the commonest(10%) side effect. Rise in CPK levels occurs infrequently. Myopathy is the only serious reaction, but is rare(< 1 per 1000). Few fatalities due to rhabdomyolysis are on record.

Myopathy and liver injury is more common when nicotinic acid/gemfibrozil or CYP3A4 inhibitors—ketoconazole/ erythromycin/ Clarithromycin/cyclosporine/HIV protease inhibitor are given concurrently.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th /e p686

questions.text: Double diffusion in two dimensions is a type of immunodiffusion(precipitation) technique which is also known as -
questions.solution:
Types of precipitation reactions -

  • Slide/tube/ring precipitation
  • Immunodiffusion(precipitation in gel)
    • Single diffusion in one dimension(Oudin's method)
    • Double diffusion in one dimension(Oakley-fulthorpe's method)
    • Single diffusion in two dimensions(Radial immunodiffusion)
    • Double diffusion in two dimensions(Ouchterlony's procedure)
  • Immunoelectrophoresis
  • Electroimmunodiffusion
    • CIEP
    • Rocket electrophoresis

Reference: Ananthanarayan 9th edition

choices.text: Extracellular matrix deposition in muscle layer

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in a 45-yr old patient suffering from chronic bronchitis?
questions.solution:
Reid index is a pathological measurement of mucosal gland proliferation in chronic bronchitis. It is assessed by comparing the thickness of the mucous glandular tissue versus the distance from epithelium to the level of cartilage.

Reid index(normally 0.4) is increased in chronic bronchitis, usually in proportion to the severity and duration of the disease.

Option A & B: The characteristic microscopic features are chronic inflammation of the airways(predominantly lymphocytes and macrophages); thickening of the bronchiolar wall due to smooth muscle hypertrophy, deposition of extracellular matrix in the muscle layer and peribronchial fibrosis; goblet cell hyperplasia; and enlargement of the mucus-secreting glands of the trachea and bronchi.

Option D: The bronchial epithelium may also exhibit squamous metaplasia and dysplasia due to the irritating and mutagenic effects of substances in tobacco smoke.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease, 10th ed. Pg 681

questions.text: A 45 year old female developed pain, an irresistible desire to move and insect crawling like sensation over legs at night which is occasionally relieved by shaking her legs. Which of the following is the drug of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
Restless leg syndrome(RLS)

It is a condition that causes an uncontrollable urge to move the legs, usually because of an uncomfortable sensation. It typically happens in the evening or night hours when a person is sitting or lying down. Moving eases the unpleasant feeling temporarily. It is also known as Ekboom syndrome.

Treatment:

  • Ropinirole, rotigotine and pramipexole are approved by the FDA for the treatment of moderate to severe RLS.
  • Gabapentin and pregabalin may work for some people with RLS.
  • Opioids can relieve mild to severe symptoms, but they may be addictive if used in high doses.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th/e p458

questions.text: During neonatal resuscitation, which of the following is a contraindication to bag and mask ventilation?
questions.solution:
During neonatal resuscitation, antenatally diagnosed or suspected diaphragmatic hernia are the only absolute contraindication for bag and mask ventilation.

Reference: Advanced NRP guidelines

questions.text: Which of the following cancers occurs by oncogenes created by translocation of chromosomes?
questions.solution:
Options A & C: Deletions involving chromosome 13q14, the site of the RB gene, are associated with retinoblastoma and deletion of the VHL tumor suppressor gene on chromosome 3p is a common event in renal cell carcinomas.

Option D: About 25% of T-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemias have small deletions of chromosome 1 that juxtapose the TAL1 proto-oncogene with a nearby active promoter, leading to overexpression of the TAL1 transcription factor.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th ed. Pg 316-317

questions.text: A 12-yr old child complains of fever and malaise. On examination, subcutaneous nodules as well as an irregular rash were observed on the forearm. He also has a history of pharyngitis about 3 weeks back. His mitral valve would appear as shown in the image. Which of the following is not a component of the distinctive Aschoff body seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
Image shows acute rheumatic mitral valvulitis superimposed on chronic rheumatic heart disease. Small vegetations(verrucae) are visible along the line of closure of the mitral valve leaflet(arrows).

During acute RF, focal inflammatory lesions are found in various tissues. Distinctive lesions in the heart—called Aschoff bodies—are composed of foci of T lymphocytes, occasional plasma cells, and plump activated macrophages called Anitschkow cells. These macrophages have abundant cytoplasm and central round-to-ovoid nuclei(occasionally binucleate) in which the chromatin condenses into a central, slender, wavy ribbon(hence the designation "caterpillar cells").

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease, 10th ed. Pg 561

questions.text: A young boy was brought to hospital with complaints of a few episodes of fast blinking and staring at the wall for around 20 seconds. EEG shows spike and wave pattern. Which of the following drugs should be used for treatment?
questions.solution:
Spike and wave pattern on EEG is typical of absence seizures.

Valproic acid is the drug of choice for absence seizures. Because of good tolerability it is also one of the First line drugs for partial seizures and GTCS.

Valproate is the most effective drug for myoclonic seizures. It is also useful in atonic seizures, in which control is often incomplete, but valproate is the drug of choice.

Mania and bipolar illness: Very commonly used as an alternative to lithium. It has also been used for panic attacks. Valproate has some prophylactic efficacy in migraine.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th/e p444

questions.text: Which of the following does not contribute to pathogenesis of aneurysms?
questions.solution:
Excessive TGF-β activity alters vascular wall remodeling, primarily of the ascending aorta, leading ultimately to diminished ECM content and integrity with aneurysmal dilation.

Option A: Weak vessel walls due to defective type III collagen synthesis are a hallmark of the vascular form of EhlersDanlos syndrome.

Option B: Increased MMP production, especially by macrophages, can contribute to aneurysm development by degrading ECM(elastin, collagens, proteoglycans, laminin, fibronectin) in all layers of the wall.

Option D: The vascular wall is weakened through loss of SMCs or the inappropriate synthesis of noncollagenous or nonelastic ECM.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease, 10th ed. Pg 505

questions.text: A 45 year old male patient with a history of ischemic heart disease was prescribed a Tricyclic antidepressant(TCA) for his depressive episode and stayed in hospital for 4 weeks and improved. What is the most important concern after discharging the patient?
questions.solution:
Adverse effects of TCAs

  • Anticholinergic - dry mouth, bad taste, constipation, epigastric distress, urinary retention blurred vision, palpitation
  • Sedation, mental confusion and weakness
  • Increased appetite and weight gain is noted with most TCAs and trazodone, but not with SSRIs, SNRIs and bupropion
  • Some patients receiving any antidepressant may abruptly ‘switch over’ to a dysphoric-agitated state or to mania. Probably, these are cases of bipolar depression, the other pole being unmasked by the antidepressant.
  • Sweating(despite antimuscarinic action) and fine tremors are relatively common.
  • Seizure threshold is lowered—fits may be precipitated, especially in children. 
  • Postural hypotension, especially in older patients. It is less severe with desipramine-like drugs.
  • Sexual distress: especially delay or interference with erection, ejaculation and occasionally with orgasm.
  • Cardiac arrhythmias, especially in patients with ischaemic heart disease. Arrhythmias may be responsible for sudden death in these patients.
  • Rashes and jaundice due to hypersensitivity are rare.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th/e p487

questions.text: A 40-yr old female patient has fatigue, purpura and epistaxis. Her laboratory reports show low Hb and platelet count, while total leukocyte count is increased to 80,000/mm3. Her coagulation profile is also altered. Image from her bone marrow aspiration is shown below. This patient's diagnosis belong to which FAB classification?
questions.solution:
Image shows bone marrow aspirate from a patient having acute promyelocytic leukemia (M3 subtype), having neoplastic promyelocytes with abnormally coarse and numerous azurophilic granules. Other characteristic findings include the presence of several cells with bilobed nuclei and a cell in the center of the field that contains multiple needle-like Auer rods.

Most patients present with complaints related to anemia, neutropenia, and thrombocytopenia, most notably fatigue, fever, and spontaneous mucosal and cutaneous bleeding.

Option A: In acute myeloid leukemia without maturation(FAB M1 subtype), myeloblasts have delicate nuclear chromatin, prominent nucleoli and fine azurophilic granules in the cytoplasm.

Option C: In acute myeloid leukemia with monocytic differentiation(FAB M5b subtype), peripheral smear shows one monoblast and five promonocytes with folded nuclear membranes.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th ed. Pg 619

questions.text: Which amongst the following is the best inotropic agent to be useful in a patient presented with right sided heart failure with pulmonary hypertension?
questions.solution:
Inotropic drugs are not used for treatment of right sided heart failure where the major treatment is diuretics and vasodilators.

Milrinone being a phosphodiesterase inhibitor acts as an inodilator. Thus, this is the only inotropic drug that should be used in right sided failure due to its ability to produce vasodilation. It is indicated in right heart failure with pulmonary hypertension.

Milrinone and Enoximone

Parenteral formulations of milrinone and enoximone are used for short-term circulation support in advanced CHF.

Enoximone is a relatively selective inhibitor of PDE3, the cGMP-inhibited cAMP PDE and main isoform involved in inotropic control in the human heart. Milrinone inhibits human heart PDE3 and PDE4 with similar potency. By increasing intracellular cAMP concentrations, they have similar actions as the β receptor agonists dobutamine and EPI, but tend to lower systemic and pulmonary vascular resistance more than do the catecholamines.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s The Pharmacological Basis of therapeutics 13th/e p541

questions.text: A 25-yr old male presents with complaints of fatigue and weakness. There is a history of recurrent jaundice. On examination, splenomegaly is observed. His CBC shows Hb 10.2 gm/dL, HCT 30%, and MCV 75.4 fL. Photograph of his peripheral blood smear is shown below. After all the further workup, splenectomy is performed. What is the most common inheritance pattern of this disease?
questions.solution:
Smear shows peripheral smear of a patient with hereditary spherocytosis(HS). Anisocytosis and several dark-appearing spherocytes with no central pallor are seen. Howell-Jolly bodies(small, dark nuclear remnants) also are seen in some of the red cells of this asplenic patient.

The characteristic clinical features are anemia, splenomegaly and jaundice. The severity varies greatly. In a small minority(mainly compound heterozygotes), HS presents at birth with marked jaundice and requires exchange transfusions.

HS is an inherited disorder caused by intrinsic defects in the red cell membrane skeleton that render red cells spheroid, less deformable and vulnerable to splenic sequestration and destruction. An autosomal dominant inheritance pattern is seen in about 75% of cases.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th ed. Pg 638-639

questions.text: A 25 year old male presented to emergency with head trauma due to a road traffic accident. In the hospital, the patient developed seizures. Emergency CT Scan revealed widespread cerebral edema. Which of the following diuretics is the drug of choice for cerebral edema in this patient?
questions.solution:
Mannitol is a low molecular weight  nonelectrolyte that is pharmacologically inert-can be given in large quantities sufficient to raise osmolarity of plasma and tubular fluid. It is minimally metabolized in the body; freely filtered at the glomerulus and undergoes limited reabsorption: therefore excellently suited to be used as osmotic diuretic.

Uses 

Mannitol is never used for the treatment of chronic edema or as a natriuretic. Its indications are -

  • Increased intracranial or intraocular tension(acute congestive glaucoma, head injury, stroke etc.): by osmotic action it encourages movement of water from brain parenchyma, CSF and aqueous humor.
  • To maintain GFR and urine flow in impending acute renal failure, e.g. in shock, severe trauma, cardiac surgery, haemolytic reactions.
  • To counteract low osmolality of plasma and ECF due to rapid haemodialysis or peritoneal dialysis(dialysis disequilibrium).

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th /e p 637

questions.text: Paramyxovirus includes
questions.solution:
Paramyxoviridae is a family of single stranded RNA viruses known to cause different types of infection in vertebrates

Paramyxoviridae includes -

questions.text: Identify the following image -
questions.solution:
Owl eye inclusion bodies are seen in Cytomegalovirus.

The most characteristic histological feature in virus infected cells is the appearance of inclusion bodies.

They may be situated in cytoplasm or nucleus or at both.

  • Cytoplasm – Poxviruses
  • Nucleus – Herpes virus
  • Both cytoplasm and nucleus – Measles

Named inclusion bodies -

  • CMV - owl eye inclusions
  • Vaccinica – Guarnieri bodies
  • Fowl pox – Bollinger bodies
  • Molluscuscontigiousum – Moluscum bodies
  • Herpes and yellow fever – Cowdry type A
  • Adenovirus and polio virus – Cowdry type B
  • Rabies – Negri bodies

Reference: Ananthanarayan 9th ed 425

choices.text: Finding of hypersegmented neutrophils is considered highly sensitive and specific
MMA and homocysteine are elevated early in the disease

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about megaloblastic anemia due to Vitamin B12 deficiency?
questions.solution:
The relative reticulocyte count(percentage) is usually normal; however, because of the severe anemia, the corrected reticulocyte count is less than 2%, the absolute reticulocyte count is low and RPI is less than 2.

Option A: Finding 5% or more neutrophils with five lobes or one neutrophil with six or more lobes is considered hypersegmentation. This finding is considered highly sensitive and specific for megaloblastic anemia.

Option B: In megaloblastic states, the bone marrow is hypercellular with megaloblastic erythroid precursors and a decreased M:E ratio.

Option C: Early megaloblastic changes can be detected by testing for methylmalonic acid(MMA) and homocysteine levels in the blood. These metabolites are intermediates in folate and cobalamin metabolism and are elevated early in functional vitamin deficiencies.

Reference: Clinical laboratory hematology 4th ed. Shirlyn McKenzie Pg 324-325

questions.text: An anxious mother brought her 4 year old daughter to the pediatrician. The girl was passing loose bulky stools for the past 20 days. This was often associated with pain in the abdomen. The pediatrician ordered a stool examination, which showed the following organisms. Identify the organism.
questions.solution:
It is a typical figure of the trophozoite and cyst of Giardia lamblia.

MORPHOLOGY

It exists in two phases -

  • Trophozoite
    • Tennis or badminton racket
    • Bilateral, symmetrical and all organs of body are paired
    • Sucking discs
    • Two nuclei
    • Four pairs of flagella
    • Axostyles
  • Cyst
    • Oval in shape
    • Contain 4 nuclei
    • Remains of flagella and margins of sucking disc
    • Axostyles

Trophozoites and cysts, both are present in the feces, but it is the resistant cyst that survives outside the body and is responsible for transmission.

Infective dose is low ingestion of as few as 10 cysts is sufficient to cause infection in humans

Reference: Parasitology by Chatterjee 12th /e p. 39

questions.text: Which of the following is not an effect of thrombin?
questions.solution:
Activation of protease-activated receptors(PARs) by thrombin is believed to mediate pro-inflammatory effects that contribute to tissue repair and angiogenesis.

Option A: Thrombin is a potent inducer of platelet activation and aggregation through its ability to activate PAR-1.

Option C: On encountering normal endothelium, thrombin changes from a procoagulant to an anticoagulant; this reversal in function prevents clots from extending beyond the site of the vascular injury.

Option D: Thrombin directly converts soluble fibrinogen into fibrin monomers that polymerize into an insoluble fibril.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th ed. Pg 122

questions.text: Cerebral malaria is caused by which species of plasmodium?
questions.solution:
Cerebral malaria is one of the complications of malaria.

It occurs mostly after infection of P falciparum. In adults, cerebral malaria is part of a multi organ disease. Patients develop fever, headache, body ache and progressively, delirium and coma.

Typical history of pediatric cerebral malaria involves a young child who rapidly develops coma after a short prodrome of fever and generalized illness. The coma may be preceded or accompanied by convulsions from which the child doesn't wake.

Reference: Harrison 18th /e p. 1692-1695

questions.text: Which of the following is not a common sign of an orbital blowout fracture?
questions.solution:
Numbness of the ipsilateral cheek, upper lip and upper teeth is a classic finding of a blowout fracture. This hypoesthesia is a result of edema or direct injury to the infraorbital nerve as it courses through the infraorbital canal in the vicinity of the fracture site.

Restrictive strabismus is present in 40% to 63% of patients with isolated floor fractures.

Enophthalmos may be present immediately or may develop later; it can be quantified by using an exophthalmometer. Acute enophthalmos is due to loss of orbital tissue into the maxillary or ethmoid sinus. Late-onset enophthalmos results from atrophy and/or contraction of orbital tissues.

Other signs that suggest enophthalmos are a deepening of the superior sulcus or a narrowed palpebral fissure.

Tenderness over the zygomaticofrontal suture is not characteristic of an isolated blowout fracture but is a common finding in a zygomaticomaxillary(tripod) fracture.

Reference: Kanski Clinical Ophthalmology 9th edition Pg.894

questions.solution:

questions.text: In a dark room on a stormy night when Ramesh was all alone, he saw a rope in the corner of a room and misinterpreted it to be a snake. This is called -
questions.solution:
Hallucination - A perception occurring in the absence of a stimulus.

Delusion - A false, fixed, firm unshakeable belief which is not in keeping with socio cultural background and which is not amenable to reasoning.

Illusion - A perception that occurs when a sensory stimulus is present but is incorrectly perceived and misinterpreted.

Delirium - Sudden onset confused thinking with reduced awareness of the surrounding.

Reference: Fish's Clinical Psychopathology, 3rd edition

questions.text: Which of the following aggressive tumors is most commonly associated with retinoblastoma?
questions.solution:
Retinoblastoma is the most common primary malignant intraocular tumor of childhood. Seen in 1:17000 live births and accounts for 3% of all childhood cancers. 6% cases are familial and the rest are sporadic.

Gene for retinoblastoma is the Rb gene(oncosuppressor gene), the locus of which is the 13q14 gene. Knudson's two hit hypothesis is used to explain the genetic pattern of retinoblastoma

Associated Tumors -

  • Osteosarcoma(most common)
  • Malignant melanoma
  • Testicular ca
  • Ewing's sarcoma
  • Wilms tumor
  • Trilateral retinoblastoma - Bilateral retinoblastoma + pineoblastoma

Reference: Kanski clinical ophthalmology 9th edition pg.860
