questions.solution: Reference: Fish's Clinical Psychopathology, 3rd edition

questions.text: Which of the following fungi is dimorphic?
questions.solution:
Dimorphic fungi

Fungi have two growth forms, such as mold(filaments) and a yeast, which develop under different growth conditions.

In host tissues or cultures at 37° C they occur as yeasts, while in the soil and in cultures at 22°C they appear as molds.

Most fungi causing systemic infections are dimorphic fungi.

Examples -

  • Coccidioides
  • Sporothrix(Sporotrichum)
  • Histoplasma
  • Candida albicans
  • Blastomyces
  • Penicilliummarneffi
  • Paracoccidioides

Candida albicans is a dimorphic fungus,while other species of candida are not dimorphic.

Reference: Ananthanarayan 8/e p. 601, 609; Jawetz 23/le p. 645

questions.text: Limitation of elevation in adduction and normal elevation in abduction is seen in -
questions.solution:
Brown's superior oblique tendon sheath syndrome: Limitation of elevation in adduction and normal elevation in abduction.

Option B - Mobius syndrome

Congenital aplasia of VI, VII, IX, XII cranial nerve nuclei.

Option A - Double elevator palsy

Paresis of SR and IO of the same eye.

Option D - Duanne's retraction syndrome

It is a syndrome where there is failure of innervation of the lateral rectus by the sixth nerve and abnormal innervation of the lateral rectus by the third nerve. It has three types

  • TYPE I: Esotropia with limitation of abduction and relatively normal adduction
  • TYPE II: Exotropia with limitation of adduction and relatively normal abduction
  • TYPE III: Limitation of both abduction and adduction with minimal deviation

Reference: Yanoff and Duker 4th edition pg no.1211

questions.text: The second intermediate host of Diphyllobothrium latum is -
questions.solution:
Diphyllobothrium latum

  • Definitive host → Man
  • First intermediate host → Cyclops
  • Second intermediate host → Fish

Other parasites that require two intermediate host are

  • Clonorchis sinensis(snail and fish)
  • Paragonimus westermani(snail and crabs/crayfish)

questions.text: Which one of the following cataract types is at increased risk for posterior capsule rupture during hydrodissection in cataract surgery?
questions.solution:

Alternative approaches to cortical dissection include hydrodelineation and viscodissection.

questions.text: A 45 year old farmer was exposed to moldy hay in his field. After exposure, he repeatedly develops breathlessness, cough, fever and malaise. A diagnosis of hypersensitivity pneumonitis is suspected. All of the below criteria are included in the clinical prediction rule for HP except?
questions.solution:
Although not meant as a set of validated diagnostic criteria, a clinical prediction rule for predicting the presence of HP has been published by the HP Study Group. They identified six statistically significant predictors for HP -

  • exposure to an antigen known to cause HP.  strongest of which was
  • presence of serum precipitins
  • recurrent symptoms
  • symptoms occurring 4–8 h after antigen exposure
  • crackles on inspiration
  • weight loss.

Reference: Harrison’s 21st edition page no.2162

questions.text: A 15 month old child presents to the PHC with cough and cold. His RR is 45/min. What is the next step in the management as per IMNCI?
questions.solution:
The baby has pneumonia as per IMNCI guidelines without any danger signs. The treatment protocol for this patient would be to prescribe appropriate antibiotics and relieve cough/fever. Call for follow up after 2 days or if the condition worsens.

Reference: IMNCI guidelines for pneumonia

questions.text: Of the following, which would be the best initial medical agent for a patient with severe asthma and newly diagnosed glaucoma?
questions.solution:
Nonselective beta-adrenergic antagonist therapy(carteolol, metipranolol, timolol) may precipitate increased shortness of breath or an asthma attack in patients with asthma. The selective beta-1 adrenergic antagonist betaxolol reduces the chance of this complication, but does not eliminate it in the severely asthmatic patient. Beta-receptor selectivity is relative and not absolute. In the patient presented, dorzolamide, a topical carbonic anhydrase inhibitor, would be the preferred medical option of the four listed. Latanoprost is also indicated for first-line therapy. Other options are brimonidine and less often used, dipivefrin and pilocarpine.

Reference: Kanski Clinical Ophthalmology 9th edition pg.367

questions.text: By what age does the Moro's reflex usually disappear?
questions.solution:
Moro’s reflex -

  • Appears by - 28-32 weeks gestation
  • Max developed at - 37 weeks
  • Lasts till - 5-6 months postnatal

(Persistence beyond 6 months is considered abnormal)

Causes of asymmetrical Moro's -

  • Fracture clavicle/humerus
  • Shoulder joint dislocation
  • Brachial plexus injury
  • Spastic hemiplegic CP

Exaggerated Moro's - seen in stage I HIE

Reference: Nelson textbook of Pediatrics, 20th ed., pg. 2798

questions.text: All of the following medications can cause acute interstitial nephritis except-
questions.solution:
Although biopsy-proven acute interstitial nephritis (AIN) accounts for no more than ~15% of cases of unexplained acute renal failure, this is likely a substantial underestimate of the true incidence.

This is because potentially offending medications are more often identified and empirically discontinued in a patient noted to have a rising serum creatinine, without the benefit of a renal biopsy to establish the diagnosis of AIN.

The classic presentation of AIN, namely, fever, rash, peripheral eosinophilia, and oliguric renal failure occurring after 7-10 days of treatment with methicillin or another β-lactam antibiotic, is the exception rather than the rule.

More often, patients are found incidentally to have a rising serum creatinine or present with symptoms attributable to acute renal failure.

All of the listed drugs except hydromorphone have been associated with AIN. Opiates are not known to cause AIN.

Reference:Harrison's 21st edition page no.2357

questions.text: A 40 year old alcoholic male presents with fever, cough with a red colored sputum and pleuritic chest pain. The X-ray of the patient is given below. Identify the causative organism.
questions.solution:
The presentation of pneumonia caused by K. pneumoniae is similar to that seen in community-acquired pneumonia. Patients may have a cough, fever, pleuritic chest pain, and shortness of breath. The sputum produced by those infected by Klebsiella is described as 'currant jelly.' (the sputum produced by those with S. pneumoniae is described as 'blood-tinged' or 'rust-colored'). The reason for this is that K. pneumoniae results in significant inflammation and necrosis of the surrounding tissue.

Klebsiella pneumonia usually affects the upper lobes but can involve the lower lobes as well

Host factors that predispose to colonization and infection are as follow:

  • Admission to an intensive care ward
  • Prolonged use of invasive devices
  • Poor infection control strategies
  • Immunocompromised especially alcoholics and diabetics
  • Prolonged use of broad-spectrum antibiotics

On Xray, cavitary pneumonia and a bulging fissure signis seen. Often there can be extensive lobar opacification with air bronchograms. A helpful feature that may help to distinguish from pneumococcal pneumonia is that Klebsiella pneumonia develops cavitation in 30-50% of cases (in comparison, cavitation is rare in pneumococcal pneumonia). This occurs early and progresses quickly. Massive necrosis (pulmonary gangrene) is a recognized complication.

Reference:Klebsiella pneumonia (https://radiopaedia.org/articles/klebsiella-pneumonia?lang=us#article-images)

questions.text: An oblique intra articular two part fracture of the base of the first metacarpal extending into the trapezio-first metacarpal joint is called as
questions.solution:
Bennett's fracture

The Bennett fracture is the most common fracture involving the base of the thumb. This fracture refers to an intraarticular fracture that separates the palmar ulnar aspect of the first metacarpal base from the remaining first metacarpal.

Rolando - a T/Y/V shaped comminuted fracture through the base of the first metacarpal bone extending into the trapezio-first metacarpal joint.

Barton - radiocarpal joint subluxation with intra articular fracture of the distal end or radius, with an intact styloid.

Chauffeur - intra articular fracture of the distal end of radius with a radial styloid fragment, with an intact radiocarpal joint.

Reference:Maheshwari Ortho 5th edition

questions.text: A 21-year-old woman gives a history of sharp pain in the lower abdomen for 2 days every month approximately 2 weeks before the menses. The most probable etiology for her pain is-
questions.solution:
Mittelschmerz is synonymous to painful ovulation. Pain is associated with the rupture of the ovarian follicle at the time of ovulation.

Characteristics -

  • It appears in the mid-menstrual period.
  • Pain is usually situated in the hypogastrium or to one iliac fossa.
  • Pain is usually located on one side and does not change side according to which ovary is ovulating.
  • Nausea and vomiting is conspicuously absent.
  • It rarely lasts for more than 12 hours.
  • It may be associated with slight vaginal bleeding or mucoid discharge.
  • The probable factors are: Increased tension in the graafian follicle just prior to rupture.
  • Peritoneal irritation by follicular fluid following ovulation.
  • Contraction of tubes and uterus.

Management

  • Assurance and analgesics
  • In refractory cases, cycles are made anovulatory by giving OCPs.

Reference: Dutta Gynae, 5th/ed p 178

questions.text: Volume of each unit of packed red cell is approximately X and a hematocrit of Y. What are X and Y respectively?
questions.solution:
Packed red blood cells are spundown and concentrated packs of red blood cells. Each unit is approximately 330 mL and has a haematocrit of 50-70%.

Packed cells are stored in a SAGM (saline- adenine- glucose- mannitol) solution to increase shelf life to 5 weeks at 2- 6°C.
Reference: bailey and love : 28th ed : pg 21

questions.text: Sudden hyperflexion of the thigh over the abdomen (McRoberts maneuver) is done for shoulder dystocia. Which of the following nerves is most commonly injured in this procedure?
questions.solution:
McRoberts' maneuver consists of forcible abduction of patients legs by sharply flexing them on the abdomen. It is the single most effective maneuver and should be the first maneuver to be performed in case of shoulder dystocia.

It results in straightening of the sacrum relative to the lumbar vertebra along with rotation of symphysis pubis towards the maternal head and it decreases the angle of pelvic inclination. Sometimes, its overzealous use may result in the separation of the maternal pubic symphysis and injury to the lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh.


Reference: Dutta Obs. 7/e

Lower compared with expiratory airway resistance

questions.text: During mechanical ventilation, inspiratory airway resistance is
questions.solution:
Airway resistance is defined as airflow obstruction in the airways. In mechanical ventilation, the degree of airway resistance is primarily affected by the length, size, and patency of the airway, endotracheal tube, and ventilator circuit.

Reference: Clinical Application of Mechanical Ventilation, Fourth Edition by David W. Chang ,page no 3

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman with hypertension and type 2 diabetes has recently started peritoneal dialysis due to kidney disease from diabetic nephropathy. Which complications of peritoneal dialysis are of concern for this patient?
questions.solution:
Peritoneal dialysis is associated with a variety of metabolic complications -

  • Albumin and other proteins can be lost across the peritoneal membrane in concert with the loss of metabolic wastes.
  • Hypoproteinemia obligates a higher dietary protein intake to maintain nitrogen balance.
  • Hyperglycemia and weight gain are also common complications of peritoneal dialysis. Several hundred calories in the form of dextrose are absorbed each day, depending on the concentration of dextrose employed.
  • Patients receiving peritoneal dialysis, particularly those with diabetes mellitus, are prone to other complications of insulin resistance, including hypertriglyceridemia.

    • On the positive side, the continuous nature of peritoneal dialysis usually allows for a more liberal diet, due to continuous removal of potassium and phosphorus-two major dietary components whose accumulation can be hazardous in end-stage renal disease.

    Reference: Harrison's 21st edition page no.2324

questions.text: Gold standard investigation when biliary atresia is suspected is-
questions.solution:
Fasting USG is the gold standard when biliary atresia is suspected. The following features may be seen -

  • shrunken gallbladder,
  • hyperechogenic liver hilum
  • triangular cord sign
  • a cyst at the liver hilum without bile duct dilatation

Option A and B - Hepatobiliary scintigraphy may reveal the diagnosis but MRCP is highly sensitive and specific in the diagnosis.

Option C - Inflammatory cells, a fibrotic liver parenchyma exhibiting signs of cholestasis and biliary neoductal structures establishes the definite diagnosis on liver biopsy.

Cholangiography is done to define the surgical anatomy of gallbladder.

Reference: BAILEY AND LOVE : 28TH ED : PG 1241

questions.text: Impetigo is caused by-
questions.solution:
Impetigo is a superficial infection of the skin by staphylococci, streptococci or both. It is highly infectious and is characterized by blisters that rupture and coalesce to form a honey-coloured crust; it usually affects children. Treatment is directed at washing the affected areas and applying topical antistaphylococcal treatments; broad-spectrum oral antibiotics are required if streptococcal infection is also implicated.

questions.text: All of the following are a part of Mirels criteria except
questions.solution:
Mirels classification is a system used to predict the highest risk of pathological fracture among long bones affected by metastases, and is based on site, location, matrix and/or presence of pain.

Classification -

  • 1 point
    • upper limb
    • involving <1/3 of bone diameter
    • blastic/sclerotic lesion
    • mild pain
  • 2 points
    • lower limb
    • involving 1/3-2/3 of bone diameter
    • mixed sclerotic/lytic lesion
    • moderate pain
  • 3 points
    • trochanteric region
    • involves >2/3 of bone diameter
    • lytic lesion
    • functional pain

This will give a minimum score of four and a maximum score of 12.

  • A score of ≥9 suggests that prophylactic fixation should be performed.
  • For score 8 lesions, treatment is based on clinical judgment
  • For lower scores, clinical management and radiotherapy is suggested.

Reference - Mirels criteria

(https://radiopaedia.org/articles/pathological-fracture-risk-mirels-classification-1)

questions.text: In an infertile woman, endometrial biopsy reveals proliferative changes. Which hormone should be preferred in her?
questions.solution:
In the question, the infertile woman's endometrial biopsy shows proliferative changes. Endometrial biopsy for infertility is taken on D 25 of cycle with the aim to rule out anovulation. Normally on these days, endometrial biopsy should show secretory changes (as ovulation occurs on D-14 and subsequently there is an increase in progesterone levels in the body). But in case of anovulation, endometrial biopsy shows proliferative changes. Thus, she has anovulatory cycles.

The hormone which should be administered here is progesterone, but that derivative of progesterone which has a weak antiovulatory effect so that it would not further inhibit ovulation, ie MDPA.

Synthetic progesterones:

Another reason for using medroxyprogesterone acetate is that it can be given intramuscularly. In the treatment of LPD (Luteal phase defect) - Intramuscular progesterone in oil produces higher plasma concentration, which is sustained for a longer period. Hence the intramuscular route of progesterone administration is considered the 'gold standard.'


Reference: KDT 6th/ed p 307

questions.text: All of the following are non bailable offenses under IPC Section 376, except-
questions.solution:
Section 376 IPC deals with the punishment of rape.

All offenses under this section are cognizable.

376(1) - Rape

Rigorous imprisonment of either description for a term which shall not be less than ten years, but which may extend to imprisonment for life, and shall also be liable to fine.

376(2) - Rape by

(a) police officer

(b) public servant

(c) A member of the armed forces

(d) person on the management or on the staff of a jail, remand home or other place of custody established by or under any law

(e) person on the management or on the staff of a hospital

(f) relative, guardian or teacher of, or a person in a position of trust or authority towards the woman

(g) rape during communal or sectarian violence

(h) rape on a woman knowing her to be pregnant;

(j) rape on a woman incapable of giving consent

(k) person in a position of control or dominance over a woman

(l) rape on a woman suffering from mental or physical disability

(m) while committing rape causes grievous bodily harm or maims or disfigures or endangers the life of a woman

(n) commits rape repeatedly on the same woman

shall be punished with rigorous imprisonment for a term which shall not be less than ten years, but which may extend to imprisonment for life, which shall mean imprisonment for the remainder of that person's natural life, and shall also be liable to fine.

376(3) - Whoever, commits rape on a woman under sixteen yearsof age shall be punished with rigorous imprisonment for a term which shall not be less than twenty years, but which may extend to imprisonment for life, which shall mean imprisonment for the remainder of that person's natural life, and shall also be liable to fine

376 A - Punishment for causing death or resulting in persistent vegetative state of victim.

shall be punished with rigorous imprisonment for a term which shall not be less than twenty years, but which may extend to imprisonment for life, which shall mean imprisonment for the remainder of that person's natural life, and with fine or with death.

376 AB - Punishment for rape on woman under twelve years of age.

shall be punished with rigorous imprisonment for a term which shall not be less than twenty years, but which may extend to imprisonment forlife, which shall mean imprisonment for the remainder of that person's natural life, and with fine or with death

376 B - Sexual intercourse by husband upon his wife during separation.

Whoever has sexual intercourse with his own wife, who is living separately, whether under a decree of separation or otherwise, without her consent, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which shall not be less than two years but which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine.

(This is the only bailable section in 376.)

376 C - Sexual intercourse by a person inauthority

Whoever, being-

(a) in a position of authority or in a fiduciary relationship

(b) a public servant

(c) superintendent or manager of a jail, remand home or other place of custody established by or under any law

(d) on the management of a hospital or being on the staff of a hospital

abuses such position or fiduciary relationship to induce or seduce any woman either in his custody or under his charge or present in the premises to have sexual intercourse with him, such sexual intercourse not amounting to the offence of rape, shall be punished with rigorous imprisonment of either description for a term which shall not be less than five years, but which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.

376 D - Gang rape

Where a woman is raped by one or more persons constituting a group or acting in furtherance of a common intention, each of those persons shall be deemed to have committed the offence of rape and shall be punished with rigorous imprisonment for a term which shall not be less than twenty years, but which may extend to life which shall mean imprisonment for the remainder of that person's natural life, and with fine.

376 DA - Punishment for gang rape on woman under sixteen years of age.

Where a woman under sixteen years of age is raped by one or more persons constituting a group or acting in furtherance of a common intention, each of those persons shall be deemed to have committed the offence of rape and shall be punished with imprisonment for life, which shall mean imprisonment for the remainder of that person's natural life, and with fine.

376 DB - Punishment for gang rape on woman under twelve years of age.

Where a woman under twelve years of age is raped by one or more persons constituting a group or acting in furtherance of a common intention, each of those persons shall be deemed to have committed the offence of rape and shall be punished with imprisonment for life, which shall mean imprisonment for the remainder of that person's natural life, and with fine, or with death.

376 E - Punishment for repeat offenders.

Whoever has been previously convicted of an offense punishable under section 376 or section 376A or 1 [section 376 AB or section 376D or section 376 DA or section 376 DB,] and is subsequently convicted of an offense punishable under any of the said sections shall be punished with imprisonment for life which shall mean imprisonment for the remainder of that person's natural life, or with death.

Reference: IndiaCode

(https://www.indiacode.nic.in/handle/123456789/1362/simple-search?page-token=fd7fe279c241&page-token-value=9615da561d5d34bd88189cd969ce743c&nccharset=9AFE50EA&query=376&btngo=&searchradio=section)

questions.text: Which of the following molecules directly activates osteoclast progenitors leading to increased bone resorption and is a target of an osteoporosis treatment drug?
questions.solution:
Resorption of bone is carried out mainly by osteoclasts, multinucleated cells that are formed by fusion of cells derived from the common precursor of macrophages and osteoclasts.

Thus, these cells derive from the hematopoietic lineage, quite different from the mesenchymal cells that become osteoblasts. Multiple factors that regulate osteoclast development have been identified.

RANK ligand, a member of the tumor necrosis factor family, is expressed on the surface of osteocytes, osteoblasts, and stromal fibroblasts. In a process involving cell-cell interactions, RANK ligand binds to the RANK receptor on osteoclast progenitors, stimulating osteoclast differentiation and activation.

Denosumab is a monoclonal antibody targeting RANK ligand. Osteoblasts synthesize and secrete the organic matrix and regulate its mineralization. They are derived from cells of mesenchymal origin.

Osteocytes regulate osteoblasts partly by secreting a potent inhibitor of Wnt signaling called sclerostin. Numerous other growth-regulatory factors affect osteoblast function, including the three closely related transforming growth factor βs, fibroblast growth factors 2 and 18, platelet-derived growth factor, and insulin-like growth factors 1 and 2.

Reference: Harrison 21st edition page 3194

questions.text: According to the Nyhus classification of inguinal hernia, a pantaloon hernia is what type?
questions.solution:
A simple and widely used classification is the Nyhus classification which categories hernia defects by size, location, and type.

A pantaloon hernia, also known as a saddlebag hernia, is defined as any combination of two adjacent hernia sacs of the femoral or inguinal region, direct or indirect inguinal hernias on the same side. Thus, examples include: femoral with direct hernias, femoral with indirect hernias, indirect with direct hernias.

  • Type I

An indirect hernia; normal size internal ring; typically in infants, children and small adults.

  • Type II

An indirect hernia; enlarged internal ring without impingement on the floor of the inguinal canal; does not extend to the scrotum.

  • Type IIIA

A direct hernia; size not taken into account.

  • Type IIIB

An indirect hernia that has grown enough to infringe upon the posterior inguinal wall; indirect sliding or scrotal hernias are regularly assigned to this category because they are often associated with the extension to direct space. This type also includes pantaloon hernia.

  • TYPE IIIC

A femoral hernia.

  • Type IV

A recurrent hernia; modifiers A to D are sometimes added that correspond with direct, indirect, femoral or mixed respectively.

Reference: Inguinal hernia

(https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK513332/)

questions.text: In a 45 years old lady with Dysfunctional Uterine Bleeding for 6 months duration, the best line of management is
questions.solution:
The first thing to do here is to rule out endometrial cancer. Usually, hysteroscopic guided biopsy would be preferred.

Aspiration, curettage, or both should clearly establish anovulatory or dyssynchronous cycles as the cause before hormone therapy is started. Above 40, anovulatory DUB is the commonest cause, but endometrial malignancy must be excluded and so endometrial sampling is performed as a first line investigation.

Option C - As far as D & C is concerned, dilatation and curettage is basically for diagnostic purposes, its therapeutic benefit is very short lived.

questions.text: All of the following form the boundaries of triangle of doom, except-
questions.solution:
The triangle of doom is bound by-

  • vas deferens medially
  • testicular vessels laterally
  • peritoneal fold inferiorly

The importance of this triangle is in this area you can find the external iliac artery and vein.

The triangle of pain is bound by -

  • iliopubic tract
  • testicular vessels
  • peritoneal fold

This triangle holds the lateral femoral cutaneous nerve, the femoral branch of the genitofemoral nerve, and the femoral nerve.

Combined together, these two triangles form the trapezoid of disaster.

Secondary to the important structures located in these two triangles it has been strongly recommended to avoid traumatic fixation of mesh in these areas as it could cause major vascular injuries or nerve injury that could result in chronic pain.

Reference: Laparoscopic inguinal hernia repair(https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK430826/#:~:text=The%20triangle%20of%20doom%20is,vessels%2C%20and%20the%20 peritoneal%20 fold)

questions.text: All of the following are components of the SOFA score except-
questions.solution:
The SOFA (Sequential Organ Failure Assessment) scoring system is composed of scores from six organ systems, graded from 0 to 4 according to the degree of dysfunction.

The score accounts for clinical interventions; it can be measured repeatedly (i.e., each day), and rising scores correlate well with increasing mortality.

The most recent sepsis consensus conference guidelines incorporated an increase of at least two points in the SOFA score from baseline as diagnostic of sepsis in the setting of suspected or documented infection.

Patients with suspected infection can be predicted to have poor outcomes typical of sepsis if they have at least two of the following clinical criteria

  • respiratory rate ≥22 breaths/min
  • altered mental status
  • systolic blood pressure ≤100 mmHg.

Recently, a new bedside clinical score using two or more of the above clinical criteria has emerged and is termed quick SOFA (qSOFA).

Reference: Harrison's principles of medicine 21st edition -page 2218

questions.text: A 20-year-old young girl, presents with a history of rapidly developing hirsutism and amenorrhea along with changes in her voice. To establish a diagnosis you would like to proceed with which of the following tests first?
questions.solution:
Specifically women with an abrupt onset, typically within several months or sudden worsening of virilising signs should prompt concern for a hormone producing ovarian or adrenal tumor. Serum testosterone levels may be used to exclude these tumors.

All masculinizing tumors have similar presentation characterized by defeminization such as breast atrophy and amenorrhoea, hirsutism, ache hoarseness of voice, muscular development, clitoromegaly and receding hairline.

Removal of the tumor restores the secondary sexual character but hoarseness of voice is permanent.

Option A - 17 OH progesterone levels are used to screen for congenital adrenal hyperplasia, which presents in childhood.

Option D - The most common cause of hirsutism in young girls - PCOS (80% cases). PCOS is not associated with hoarseness and hirsutism is not rapidly developing. LH and FSH levels help in the diagnosis. Here, testosterone levels though raised are less than 200 ng/dl.

Option B - It is important to know that we are measuring the levels of testosterone and not DHEA because the main source of DHEA is adrenal gland and not ovary.

Reference: Shaw 15th/ed p 380; Williams Gynae 1st/ed p 391

questions.solution:
Even coincidental events (such as in option B) are considered to be AEFIs as an AEFI doesn't necessarily have a causal relationship with the vaccine.

An AEFI is any untoward medical occurrence which follows immunization and which does not necessarily have a causal relationship with the usage of the vaccine. The adverse event may be any unfavorable or unintended sign, abnormal laboratory finding, symptom or disease. Reported adverse events can either be true adverse events, i.e. really a result of the vaccine or immunization process, or coincidental events that are not due to the vaccine or immunization process but are temporally associated with immunization.

questions.text: A 35 year old woman presents to you with 5 months of stiff small joints of the hand and wrist. Pain is worse in the morning on waking up. On examination, the wrists, MCP and PIP joints are warm and swollen. Which of the following investigations is most specific for confirming the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given history is suggestive of inflammatory arthritis.

Anti Cyclic citrullinated peptide level is the most specific for the diagnosis of RA.

The presence of serum anti-CCP antibodies has about the same sensitivity as serum RF for the diagnosis of RA. However, its diagnostic specificity approaches 95%, so a positive test for anti-CCP antibodies in the setting of an early inflammatory arthritis is useful for distinguishing RA from other forms of arthritis.

There is some incremental value in testing for the presence of both RF and anti-CCP, as some patients with RA are positive for RF but negative for anti-CCP and vice versa.

The presence of RF or anti-CCP antibodies also has prognostic significance, with anti-CCP antibodies showing the most value for predicting worse outcomes.

Option B - RA Factor is useful for the screening of Rheumatoid Arthritis.

Option D - CRP is a nonspecific marker of inflammation.

Option A - Xray had the least sensitivity to detect bone erosion in the early stage of RA.

Reference: Harrison's 21st edition page no.2759

questions.text: All of the following are causes of distributive shock except -
questions.solution:
Shock is characterized by decreased oxygen delivery and/or increased oxygen consumption or inadequate oxygen utilization leading to cellular and tissue hypoxia. It most commonly manifests as hypotension (SBP less than 90 mmHg or MAP less than 65 mmHg).

There are mainly four broad categories of shock -

  • Distributive Shock - characterized by peripheral vasodilatation. Types of distributive shock include:
    • Septic Shock - Sepsis is defined as life-threatening organ dysfunction resulting from dysregulated host response to infection. Septic shock is a subset of sepsis with severe circulatory, cellular, and metabolic abnormalities resulting in tissue hypoperfusion manifested as hypotension which requires vasopressor therapy and elevated lactate levels (more than 2 mmol/L)
    • Systemic Inflammatory Response Syndrome - SIRS is a clinical syndrome of the vigorous inflammatory response caused by either infectious or noninfectious causes. Infectious causes include pathogens such as gram-positive (most common) and gram-negative bacteria, fungi, viral infections (e.g., respiratory viruses), parasitic (e.g., malaria), rickettsial infections. Noninfectious causes of SIRS include but are not limited to pancreatitis, burns, fat embolism, air embolism, and amniotic fluid embolism
    • Anaphylactic Shock - Anaphylactic shock is a clinical syndrome of severe hypersensitivity reaction mediated by immunoglobulin E (Ig-E), resulting in cardiovascular collapse and respiratory distress due to bronchospasm. The immediate hypersensitivity reactions can occur within seconds to minutes after the presentation of the inciting antigen. Common allergens include drugs (e.g., antibiotics, NSAIDs), food, insect stings, and latex.
    • Neurogenic Shock - Neurogenic shock can occur in the setting of trauma to the spinal cord or the brain. The underlying mechanism is the disruption of the autonomic pathway resulting in decreased vascular resistance and changes in vagal tone.
    • Endocrine Shock - Due to underlying endocrine etiologies such as adrenal failure (Addisonian crisis) and myxedema.
  • Hypovolemic Shock - Hypovolemic shock is characterized by decreased intravascular volume and increased systemic venous assistance (compensatory the mechanism to maintain perfusion in the early stages of shock). In the later stages of shock due to progressive volume depletion, cardiac output also decreases and manifests as hypotension. Hypovolemic shock divides into two broad subtypes
    • Hemorrhagic hypovolemic shock -
    • Gastrointestinal bleed (both upper and lower gastrointestinal bleed (e.g., variceal bleed, portal hypertensive gastropathy bleed, peptic ulcer, diverticulosis) trauma
    • Vascular etiologies (e.g., aortoenteric fistula, ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm, tumor eroding into a major blood vessel)
    • Spontaneous bleeding in the setting of anticoagulant use (in the setting of supratherapeutic INR from drug interactions)
  • Non-hemorrhagic hypovolemic shock - 
    • GI losses - the setting of vomiting, diarrhea, NG suction, or drains.
    • Renal losses - medication-induced diuresis, endocrine disorders such as hypoaldosteronism.
    • Skin losses/insensible losses - burns, Stevens-Johnson syndrome, Toxic epidermal necrolysis, heatstroke, pyrexia.
    • Third-space loss - in the setting of pancreatitis, cirrhosis, intestinal obstruction, trauma.
  • Cardiogenic Shock - Due to intracardiac causes leading to decreased cardiac output and systemic hypoperfusion. Different subtypes of etiologies contributing to cardiogenic shock include:
    • Cardiomyopathies - include acute myocardial infarction affecting more than 40% of the left ventricle, acute myocardial infarction in the setting of multi-vessel coronary artery disease, right ventricular myocardial infarction, fulminant dilated cardiomyopathy, cardiac arrest (due to myocardial stunning), myocarditis.
    • Arrhythmias - both tachy- and bradyarrhythmias
    • Mechanical - severe aortic insufficiency, severe mitral insufficiency, rupture of papillary muscles, or chordae tendineae trauma rupture of ventricular free wall aneurysm.
  • Obstructive Shock - Mostly due to extracardiac causes leading to a decrease in the left ventricular cardiac output
    • Pulmonary vascular - due to impaired blood flow from the right heart to the left heart. Examples include hemodynamically significant pulmonary embolism, severe pulmonary hypertension.
    • Mechanical - impaired filling of the right heart or due to decreased venous return to the right heart due to extrinsic compression. Examples include tension pneumothorax, pericardial tamponade, restrictive cardiomyopathy, constrictive pericarditis

Reference: Shock

(https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK531492/#:~:text=There%20are%20 broadly%20four%20 types,cardiogenic%2C%20 hypovolemic%2C%20and%20 obstructive)

questions.text: A pregnant female presents with fever. On lab investigations, her Hb was decreased (7 mg%), TLC was normal and the platelet count was also decreased. Peripheral smear shows fragmented RBCs. Which is the least probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A - DIC may present with sudden onset of fever (as the M/c cause of DIC is sepsis). Excessive bleeding may lead to anemia. Platelet consumption may lead to thrombocytopenia. Leukocyte count is not affected. Intravascular microangiopathic hemolysis can lead to schistocytes on peripheral smear.

Option B - TTP i.e Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura, presents with a pentad of - Fever, Microangiopathic haemolytic anemia (leading to anemia and fragmentation of RBCs), Thrombocytopenia, Neurologic symptoms and Renal failure.

Option C - HELLP syndrome presents with the combination of - Hemolysis because of which fragmented RBCs may be seen; Elevated liver enzymes and; Low platelet count. Fever may or may not be present.

Option D - Evans syndrome is an autoimmune disease in which an individual's antibodies attack their own red blood cells and platelets. Its overall pathology resembles a combination of autoimmune haemolytic anemia and idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura. Autoimmune hemolysis leads to the formation of spherocytes and not schistocytes. Schistocytes are fragmented RBCs that are the result of microangiopathic hemolysis. Autoimmune destruction of RBCs leads to the formation of spherocytes.

Hence, Evans syndrome is the least likely possibility in this clinical scenario.

Reference: Harrison 20/e, p 979; Williams Obs 23/e, p 786; Hoffman: Hematology: Basic Principle and Practice, 5/e

questions.text: The dose of radiation per film in mammography is approximately -
questions.solution:
Mammography in two planes and ultrasonography are the first line investigations for imaging the breast. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is a valuable adjunctive diagnostic tool because of its high sensitivity for breast pathology. Mammography is also used as an initial screening tool for asymptomatic women in population-based programmes. Radiographs are taken by placing the breast in direct contact with ultrasensitive flm and exposing it to low-voltage, high-amperage x-rays.

The dose of radiation is approximately 1 mGy per film. Mammography should be the first investigation in older women who present with breast symptoms.

Ancillary signs of malignancy such as lymphadenopathy, breast oedema and skin or areolar thickening or retraction may be seen in advanced cases. The mammographic and ultrasonographic features are not diagnostic of cancer; biopsy is required for definitive diagnosis in lesions with a Breast Imaging Reporting and Data System (BIRADS) score of at least 4 or 5.

Reference: BAILEY AND LOVE : 28TH ED ;PG 916

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman presents with infertility and palpable pelvic mass. Her CA-125 level is 91 mIU/mL. The most probable diagnosis is -
questions.solution:
CA-125

  • This is a non-specific tumor marker
  • CA-125 is a glycoprotein which is normally not produced by ovarian epithelium but may be produced by both malignant and benign epithelial ovarian tumors.
  • Cut off level of CA-125 is < 35 U/mL.
  • Causes of raised levels -
    • Physiological
      • Pregnancy
      • Menstruation
    • Pathological
      • Endometriosis
      • Salpingitis
      • Fibroids
      • PID
      • Ascites
      • Pancreatitis
      • Renal failure
      • Tb
      • Heart failure
      • Malignancies - ovarian, endometrial, pancreatic

Palpable mass may also be present in all the four conditions.

Infertility is a feature of endometriosis and tuberculosis. But for ovarian cancers, infertility (due to use of ovulation inducing drugs) is a risk factor, not a feature or presenting symptom.

The patient is 35 years, which also favors endometrioma (endometriosis).

Peak incidence of invasive epithelial ovarian cancer (most common ovarian cancer) is at 56-60 years of age and for borderline tumors, the average age is around 46 years.

Patients with tuberculosis are in their twenties commonly, the maximum age incidence at diagnosis being 28 years.

Also in tuberculosis, CA 125 has least significance as it is neither used for diagnosis nor for follow up

Reference: Novak Gynecology 14th/ed pp 1466, 1146, 1147; William's Gynae 1st/ed pp 232, 210

questions.text: Which of the following is the treatment of choice for thyroglossal cyst?
questions.solution:
Treatment must include excision of the whole thyroglossal tract, which involves removal of the body of the hyoid bone and the suprahyoid tract through the tongue base to the vallecula at the site of the primitive foramen caecum, together with a core of tissue on either side. This operation is known as Sistrunk's operation and minimizes recurrence, most notably from small side branches of the thyroglossal tract.

Option A - Seabrook operation is done for parotid fistulae.

Option C - Homan's procedure is done for lymphedema. It involves elliptical excisions of skin and subcutaneous tissue with primary closure.

Option D - Thompson procedure is done for lymphedema.

REF: BAILEY AND LOVE : 28TH ED : PG 807

questions.text: A 30 year old man presented with high grade fever, cough, nausea, diarrhea and mental confusion for 4 days. X-ray revealed bilateral pneumonitis .What is the most likely causative pathogen?

The organism causing atypical pneumonia out of four is Legionella pneumophila.

The presence of confusion can be explained by hyponatremia due to SIADH.

Clinical features of Legionnaires Disease

  • Diarrhea
  • High grade fever
  • Hyponatremia
  • Failed to respond to B-lactam antibiotics and aminoglycoside
  • Occurrence of illness in an environment in which the potable water supply is known to contaminated with Legionella

questions.solution:
Most common site of ureteric injury during hysterectomy -

Where it is crossed by the uterine artery > Near pelvic brim

Pelvic ureter

  • It extends from its crossing over the pelvic brim up to its opening into the bladder.
  • Measures 13-15 cm in length and has a diameter of 5 mm.
  • The ureter enters the pelvis in front of the bifurcation of the common iliac artery anterior to the sacroiliac joint. As it courses downwards, it lies anterior to the internal iliac artery medial to the obturator nerves and vessels and forms the posterior boundary of ovarian fossa.
  • On reaching the ischial spine, it lies over the pelvic floor and as it courses forwards and medially on the base of the broad ligament, it is crossed by the uterine artery anteriorly.
  • Hereafter, it enters into the ureteric tunnel and lies close to the supravaginal part of the cervix, about 1.5 cm lateral to it.

Reference: JB Sharma textbook of Gynecology, pg14

questions.text: Supermicrosurgery, involving micro neurovascular anastomosis of vessels and coaptation of single nerve fascicles has further expanded the field of precision surgery. What is the size of nerve fascicles (in mm) that can be repaired using this technique?
questions.solution:
Supermicrosurgery involving microneurovascular anastomosis of vessels and coaptation of single nerve fascicles of the order of 0.3 - 0.8 mm has further expanded the field of surgery. It has enabled the reconstruction of fingertip injuries, which traditionally would have been treated with amputation, and the creation of lymphaticovenous anastomosis for the treatment of chronic lymphoedema.

Another advancement in precision surgery is the Mohs surgery. Also called Micro Graphically Oriented Histographic Surgery.

It is a procedure used to treat certain types of skin cancer, penile cancer, and soft tissue sarcoma of the skin. During Mohs micrographic surgery, one layer of tissue at the site of a visible cancer is removed at a time and checked under a microscope for the presence of cancer. This process is repeated until all cancerous tissue has been removed.

This type of surgery removes as little normal tissue as possible.

Reference: bailey and love : 28th ed : pg 699

questions.text: The average daily dietary nutrient intake level sufficient to meet the nutrient requirements of nearly all (97-98 per cent) healthy individuals in a particular life stage and gender group is the -
questions.solution:
Recommended dietary allowance (RDA): The average daily dietary nutrient intake level sufficient to meet the nutrient requirement of nearly all (97-98 per cent) healthy individuals in a particular life stage and gender group.

Adequate intake : A recommended average daily intake level based on observed or experimentally determined approximations or estimates of nutrient intake by a group (or groups) of apparently healthy people, that are assumed to be adequate - used when an RDA cannot be determined. In the Indian context, this is referred to as '·acceptable intake".

Tolerable upper intake level (UL) : The highest average daily nutrient intake level that is likely to pose no risk of adverse health effects for almost all individuals in the general population. As intake increases above the UL, the potential risk of adverse effects increases.

Estimated average requirement (EAR): The average daily nutrient intake level estimated to meet the requirement of half of the healthy individuals in a particular life stage and gender group.

questions.text: A 30 year old female patient has severe diarrhea and vomiting. She develops hypokalemia. All of the following are ECG changes in the hypokalemia except -
questions.solution:
Hypokalemia has prominent effects on cardiac, skeletal, and intestinal muscle cells. In particular, hypokalemia is a major risk factor for both ventricular and atrial arrhythmias.

Hypokalemia predisposes to digoxin toxicity by a number of mechanisms, including reduced competition between K+ and digoxin for shared binding sites on cardiac Na+/K+-ATPase subunits.

Electrocardiographic changes in hypokalemia include broad flat T waves, ST depression, and QT prolongation; these are most marked when serum K+ is <2.7 mmol/L. Hypokalemia can thus be an important precipitant of arrhythmia in patients with additional genetic or acquired causes of QT prolongation.

Hypokalemia also results in hyperpolarization of skeletal muscle, thus impairing the capacity to depolarize and contract; weakness and even paralysis may ensue. It also causes skeletal myopathy and predisposes to rhabdomyolysis. Finally, the paralytic effects of hypokalemia on intestinal smooth muscle may cause intestinal ileus.

Reference - Harrison's 21st edition page no. 350

questions.text: A 25-year-old G1P0 female at 25 wks of gestation comes to you for antenatal check up. She has had an uncomplicated pregnancy but has a 5 year history of genital herpes infection. She is usually asymptomatic and has had 3 flare-ups in the past 5 years. She is concerned about exposing her unborn child to the infection. What is the most appropriate counsel you can offer to this patient?
questions.solution:
HSV infection in pregnancy -

  • The most common time of mother to child transmission is at the time of delivery. About 50% women with HSV in the first trimester abort while infection in the second half can lead to IUGR and preterm labor.
  • ACOG does not recommend a routine screening for HSV.
  • Viral isolation is the defective means of diagnosis for HSV infection. Specimens are obtained from any active lesions as well as from cervix and vagina. PCR can also be done.
  • DOC during pregnancy - Acyclovir (safe in lactation also) × 7-10 days
  • ACOG recommends daily viral therapy at or beyond 36 weeks for women who have recurrences during pregnancy as it decreases the outbreaks at term and so decreased need for cesarean
  • Cesarean section is indicated for women with active genital lesions or in patients having prodromal symptoms of herpes viz genital pain and tingling. Cesarean is not indicated in women with a h/o HSV infection but no active genital tract lesion/prodromal symptoms at the time of delivery.
  • If no active breast lesions are present, the patient can breastfeed.

Reference - Williams 23/e, p 1238

questions.text: Total intravenous anesthesia (tiVa) refers to anesthesia that is provided solely by the intravenous route, the drug that is less likely to be used as such:
questions.solution:
Drugs with a small volume of distribution, rapid metabolism (with no active metabolites), high clearance and short half life are ideal for infusions.

Remifentanil, propofol and alfentanil are the three main anesthetic agents used in TiVA.

Thiopentone accumulates on repeated doses, so cannot be used as infusion for long hours, can lead to thiopentone or barbiturate coma.

Reference: PRIMARY FRCA IN A BOX, page no 179

choices.text: Both provoked and unprovoked bites need post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP)
Washing of wounds with soap and water is desirable for at least 15 minutes
If suturing is unavoidable, the wound must be cleaned, sutured, and rabies immunoglobulin (RIG) should be infiltrated in and around the wound after suturing
Rabies vaccine is not contra-indicated in pregnancy

questions.text: All of the following are true about the post-exposure management of a dog/cat bite wound except -
questions.solution:
If the wound has to be sutured, RIG must first be infiltrated in and around the wound before suturing.

A bite by a provoked animal does not mean that the animal is not rabid. Therefore, a provoked dog bite should also be managed as exposure and post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) should be started immediately (option A).

Washing of wounds is desirable up to 15 minutes and should be carried out as soon as possible with soap and water (option B).

As rabies is a nearly 100% fatal disease, there is no contraindication to post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP). Moreover, the rabies vaccine does not have any adverse effect on pregnant women, course of pregnancy, fetus or lactating mother (option D).

Reference: National Rabies Prophylaxis Guidelines, 2019

(https://ncdc.gov.in/WriteReadData/linkimages/NationalGuidelinesforRabiesprophylaxis2019)

(https://www.who.int/news-room/fact-sheets/detail/rabies#:~:text=extensive%20washing%20with%20 water%20 and,into%20the%20 wound%2C%20if%20 indicated)

questions.text: CSF rhinorrhea occurs due to fracture of -
questions.solution:
CSF discharging from the nose is known as CSF rhinorrhoea. Cerebrospinal fluid is a clear colorless fluid that bathes the brain and spinal cord, cushioning them against trauma. In fact in literal terms the brain and spinal cord floats in the cerebrospinal fluid. The specific gravity of the brain is only 4% of that of CSF, hence it could float easily in the CSF.

The high pressure leaks are commonly encountered in the cribriform area. This is due to the fragility and unique anatomy in this area i.e. (prolongation of the subarachnoid space along the olfactory filaments). The leak during these conditions functions as a safety valve alleviating the increased intracranial pressure. These high pressure leaks are associated with slow growing tumors and 1/4 of them have hydrocephalus.

Pituitary neoplasms are the most common type of intracranial tumor found, next common are the posterior cranial fossa lesions. Direct invasion of the skull base is not the usual mechanism of this leak.

Closure of these leaks may worsen the condition of the patient if the causative lesion is left untreated.

Reference. - Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, P L Dhingra, 8th edition

questions.text: Which of the following formulae correctly gives the fluid requirements for an adult patient with electric burns?
questions.solution:
The current ATLS guidelines for fluid requirements in burns patients -

  • Adult with 2°/3° burns -

TBSA% burn * wt(kg) * 2

  • Child with 2°/3° burns -

TBSA% burn x wt(kg) x 3

  • Adult/child with 4° burns -

TBSA% burn x wt(kg) x 4

  • Adult/child with electric burns -

TBSA% burn x wt(kg) x 4

Out of the total, half is given in 8 hours and the rest over 16 hours to complete the 24-hour resuscitation time frame.

REFERENCE: BAILEY AND LOVE : 28TH ED : PG 671

questions.text: A lady has recurrent abortions in the First trimester with a history of autosomal recessive disorder in the family. Which of the following statements regarding this are true?
questions.solution:
Autosomal recessive inheritance is the single largest category of Mendelian disorders. They have the following features -

  • The trait does not usually affect the parents but siblings may show the disease (Option C).
  • Siblings have one chance in four of being affected (i.e. recurrence risk is 25% for each birth).
  • Consanguineous marriage may be the cause (Option A).
  • The expression of the defect tends to be more uniform than in autosomal dominant disorders.
  • Complete penetrance is common (Option B).
  • Onset is frequently early in life.

Reference. - Robbin's 7th edition, p 151

questions.text: You are called to the operating room. The general surgeons have operated on a woman to rule out appendicitis and the signs of an abdominal pregnancy with a 16 week fetus and placenta attached to the omentum. The best course of action in this case is -
questions.solution:
Abdominal pregnancy

Management includes urgent laparotomy irrespective of period of gestation.

The ideal surgery is to remove the entire sac, fetus, placenta and membrane. This can be done if the placenta is attached to a removable organ like the uterus or the broad ligament.

If the placenta is attached to some vital organs, it is better to take out the fetus and leave behind the placenta and the sac after tying and cutting the cord with its placental attachment. Absorption of placenta occurs by aseptic autolysis.

If placenta is left, its involution is monitored by serum hCG and USG.

Dangers related to leaving placenta attached -

  • Infection and abscess
  • Adhesions
  • Intestinal obstruction
  • Wound dehiscence

Reference. - Dutta Obs. 7/e, p 188; Williams Obs. 23/e, p 250, 251

questions.text: A 22-year-old primigravida is admitted at 39 weeks gestation with painless antepartum hemorrhage. On examination, the uterus is soft, non-tender and the head is engaged. What is the next best step in her management ?
questions.solution:
Patient is presenting with painless vaginal bleeding and the uterus is soft and nontender. These findings point towards the diagnosis of placenta previa.

(In abruption - bleeding is accompanied by pain, the uterus is tense, tender and rigid)

The gestational age is 39 weeks i.e., fetal maturity is attained so pregnancy has to be terminated, either vaginally or by cesarean section.

Before termination of pregnancy, vaginal examination should be done in OT (keeping everything ready for cesarean section) to confirm the diagnosis of placenta previa.

Option B - Vaginal examination should not be done outside the operation theater as it can provoke further separation of placenta with torrential bleeding which may be fatal.

These days the need for carrying out vaginal examination in OT has decreased as the placental location can always be ascertained sonographically.

Reference. - Dutta Obs. 7/e, p 249

questions.text: In a patient with recurrent seizures, which of the following may help in mapping of a seizure focus under general anesthesia by enhancing the EEG activity or inducing the seizure?
questions.solution:
Etomidate may activate seizure foci, manifesting as fast activity on the EEG. For this reason, etomidate should also be used with caution in patients with focal epilepsy. Conversely, this characteristic has been observed to facilitate localization of seizure foci in patients undergoing cortical resection of epileptogenic tissue. Despite the EEG effects, etomidate also possesses anticonvulsant properties and has been used to terminate status epilepticus.

Pentothal and diazepam have anti epileptic activity.

Isoflurane use is also not associated with any epileptic activity.

Reference: Stoelting's pharmacology and physiology in anesthetic practice 5th edition pg169

questions.text: Which of the following gives the magnitude of the approximate completed family size?
questions.solution:
Total fertility rate represents the average number of children a woman would have if she were to pass through her reproductive years bearing children at the same rates as the women now in each age group. It is computed by summing the age-specific fertility rates for all ages; if 5-year age groups are used, the sum of the rates is multiplied by 5. This measure gives the approximate magnitude of "completed family size".

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th Edition, page 540

questions.text: Most common congenital anomaly of the larynx is -
questions.solution:
Laryngomalacia is the most frequent cause of stridor or noisy breathing in infants. It occurs as a result of a floppy portion of the larynx that has not yet developed the strength to provide rigid support of the airway.

During inspiration, negative pressure is created through the larynx, which results in a collapse of these structures into the airway and a nar- rower breathing passage. The partial obstruction is the source of the noise with breathing.

The hallmark sign includes a high pitched or squeaky intermittent sound noted mostly on inspiration. It is usually more prominent when the infant is lying on his/her back, crying, feeding, excited or has a cold. This is usually first noticed in the first few weeks of life. It may worsen over the first few months and become louder. This is because as the baby grows, the inspiratory force is greater, which causes greater collapse of the laryngeal structures into the airway. This is usually at its worst at 3-6 months and then gradually improves as the rigidity of the cartilage improves. Most children are symptom free by 12 months.

Reference. - Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, P L Dhingra, 8th edition

questions.text: A 28 year old female presented with joint pain for 6 months. She has no visible deformity. She also has alopecia. Urine examination shows proteinuria 3+ with granular casts, no hematuria is seen. In serology, ANA is positive and RA factor negative. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A young female with alopecia and joint pain is prone to develop autoimmune disease. No joint deformity signifies non-erosive arthritis. Proteinuria is suggestive of renal involvement.

Option A - MCTD is ruled out as RA factor is negative and Anti RNP antibody is not mentioned.

Option B - RA has RA factor positive and has erosive arthritis.

Option D - In Ankylosing spondylitis HLA B27 is positive.

Reference. - Harrison's 21st edition page no.2741

questions.text: All of the following are operative principles in damage control surgery except -
questions.solution:
Stages of Damage Control

Damage control surgery (DCS) is divided into four distinct stages

  • the decision to perform DCS
  • the operation
  • intensive care unit resuscitation
  • second-look/definitive operation.

Decision to perform DCS

  • Preoperative decision to perform a DCS procedure is frequently made in patients with multisystem trauma.
  • Absolute indications for DCS:
    • Base deficit >8 mEq/L or worsening base deficit
    • pH < 7.2
    • Hypotension < 90 mm Hg systolic
    • Hypothermia < 34° C
    • PTT > 60 seconds
    • Operative “clinical” coagulopathy
  • Early recognition of significant physiologic derangement and the need for DCS are critical as inability to correct pH >7.21 and PTT >70 is associated with near certain mortality.
  • Initial resuscitation should begin in the emergency department and continue in the operating room following correction of deficit and using a massive transfusion program as indicated.

DCS operative principles

  • The goal of DCS is a short operating time, followed by transport to an intensive care unit.
  • Control of hemorrhage
    • Ligation of named vascular structures and/or temporary vascular clamps
    • Vascular shunting
    • Abdominal packing: packs are inserted into the right upper quadrant, left upper quadrant, and pelvis. The bowel should be separated from laparotomy pads.
  • Control of contamination
    • Bowel injuries may be quickly closed or resected with stapled ends left in discontinuity.
    • Delay definitive repair of injury including time-consuming anastomoses and ostomies
  • Prevent hypothermia.
    • Warm operating room.
    • All resuscitation fluids and blood products must be warmed to 38.0º C or higher.
    • Continuous use of convective warming devices
  • Temporary abdominal closure (TAC)
    • Allows 'easy access' for planned next operative intervention
    • TAC dressing-specific drains are placed in the packing, and a seal is created over the wound with the use of Ioban dressing. These drains are then connected to wall suction.
    • Additional abdominal drains may be used as well.
  • Angiography/embolization
    • If pelvic bleeding is suspected, the patient may be transferred to the angiography suite at this time. Significant hepatic parenchymal hemorrhage may also be controlled with angiography.

Restoration of homeostasis in the intensive care unit

  • Rewarming
    • Warm room temperature and other convective measures of warming, such as warming blankets and lamps, are used to maintain body temperature >35º C.
    • Use of fluid warmer for administration of resuscitative crystalloids and blood products is mandatory.
    • Continuous arteriovenous rewarming (CAVR) is occasionally performed when body temperature is less than 35º C.
  • Careful fluid resuscitation
    • Resuscitation may be guided by early use of a pulmonary artery catheter.
    • If massive bleeding resumes, the patient is returned emergently to the operating room for cessation of likely surgical bleeding.
    • Avoid over-resuscitation.
    • Monitor bladder pressure. Bladder pressures >20 mm Hg should raise concern for intra-abdominal hypertension (IAH) and >30 mm Hg for abdominal compartment syndrome (ACS).
  • Ventilatory support
    • If possible, maintain tidal volumes at 6 mL/kg ideal body weight.
  • Negative fluid balance
    • When physiologic balance is restored, natural mobilization of third space fluids may be aided with a continuous furosemide drip, titrated to a net negative balance per hour.
    • This facilitates abdominal wall closure.

Definitive operative intervention

  • Ideally performed at 24 to 36 hours, later if indications of physiologic derangement persist
  • Removal of packs, with replacement if necessary
  • Secondary survey of the abdomen: missed injuries at the time of damage control surgery are not uncommon.
  • Restoration of gastrointestinal and vascular continuity if necessary
  • Performance of other definitive procedures, such as ostomy placement
  • Abdominal closure if possible. If bowel edema prevents this, several techniques (e.g., Wittman patch) can be employed to help reapproximate fascial edges in stages.
  • Multiple 'second-looks' may be needed.

Reference. - Damage Control Surgery (https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/medicine-and-dentistry/damage-control-surgery)

questions.text: Maturation of collagen in the wound bed leads to increased tensile strength in the wound. At what time post injury is the maximal skin strength reached?
questions.solution:
The remodeling phase begins 2-3 weeks after injury and lasts for a year or more. This phase is characterized by maturation of collagen. Type III collagen, which is prevalent during proliferation, is replaced by the stronger type I collagen until the normal skin ratio of 4:1 type I to type III collagen is re-established.

The collagen becomes more cross-linked and uniformly aligned.

This maturation of collagen leads to increased tensile strength in the wound, which is maximal 12 weeks post injury and represents approximately 80% of the uninjured skin strength.

REFERENCE: BAILEY AND LOVE : 28TH ED ; PG 25

choices.text: Shift of apical impulse laterally and upwards in left 4th intercostal space

questions.text: Which of the following cardiovascular changes is physiological in the last trimester of pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Clinical findings related to cardiovascular changes occuring during pregnancy -

  • The resting heart rate increases by about 10-15 bpm.
  • Apex beat shifts to the 4th intercostal space, 2.5 cm outside the mid clavicular line (as heart is pushed upwards, outward, with slight rotation to left).
  • Slightly enlarged cardiac silhouette. (marked enlarged cardiac silhouette is not normal in pregnancy)
  • Exaggerated splitting of the first heart sound (both components loud).
  • Second heart sound is normal
  • Third heart sound is loud and easily auscultated.
  • Murmurs -
    • Grade II systolic ejection murmur is audible in aortic or pulmonary area at about 10-12 weeks due to expanded intravenous volume. It disappears in the beginning of the postpartum period.
    • Continuous hissing murmur audible over tricuspid area in left 2nd and 3rd intercostal spaces known as Mammary souffle.
  • ECHO - Shows increased left atrial and ventricular diameters.
  • ECG - Shows left axis deviation.
  • CXR - straightening of left heart border.

Reference. - Dutta Obs. 7/e, p 52; Williams Obs. 23/e, p 118, 119, 960

questions.text: The Inhalational agents are influenced by a number of patient and environmental factors. The factors that increases the Minimum Alveolar Concentration or decreasing the potency of the agent are -
questions.solution:
MAC is reduced by:

  • other depressant drugs (e.g. opioids, sedatives, other inhalational agents).
  • CNS depletion of catecholamines, e.g. by α-methyldopa, reserpine.
  • hypothermia
  • hypoxaemia/hypotension.
  • pregnancy, possibly due to increased progesterone levels.
  • extremes of age.

MAC is increased in:

  • children
  • hyperthermia
  • hyperthyroidism
  • chronic alcoholism

It is unaffected by duration of anesthesia, sex, acidosis/alkalosis, hypercapnia or hypocapnia.

Reference: FRCA A to Z , edition 5, page no 381

questions.text: A 30 year old farmer from Bihar comes to you with complaints of progressive stiffness in both legs. On enquiring about his diet, he says his staple diet is based on a pulse with a peculiar triangular shape. Regarding his most likely diagnosis, which of the following is not used for the removal of the implicated toxin?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in this case is lathyrism. Nalgonda technique is not used for the removal of the toxin in lathyrism; it is used for the defluoridation of water,

The given clinical vignette of a 30 year old farmer from Bihar with progressive leg stiffness is suggestive of neurolathyrism. Neurolathyrism is a crippling disease of the nervous system characterized by gradually developing spastic paralysis of lower limbs, occurring mostly in adults consuming the pulse, Lathyrus sativus in large quantities. Neurolathyrism is prevalent in parts of Madhya Pradesh, Uttar Pradesh, Bihar and Orissa.

The seeds of Lathyrus have a characteristic triangular shape and grey colour. Like other pulses, Lathyrus is a good source of protein, but for its toxin which affects the nerves. It is eaten mostly by the poor agricultural labourer because it is relatively cheap. 

The toxin present in Lathyrus seeds has been identified as beta oxalyl amino alanine (BOAA).

Removal of the toxin can be done by:

  • Steeping method (option A): Since the toxins are water soluble, they can be removed by soaking the pulse in hot water. A large quantity of water is boiled and the pulse is soaked in hot water for 2 hours; after which the soaked water is drained off completely. The pulse is washed again with clean water, then drained off and dried in the sun. The pulse is then used for consumption.
  • Parboiling (option B): An improved method of detoxicating the pulse is "parboiling" as is done in the case of parboiled rice. This technique is suitable for large scale operation. Simple soaking in lime water overnight followed by boiling is credited to destroy the toxin. This treatment also destroys trypsin inhibitors. Lime is easily available as it is used with betel leaves.

Other measures for controlling the disease:

  • Vitamin C prophylaxis
  • Banning the crop
  • Education
  • Genetic approach by propagating low-toxin producing varieties
  • Socio-economic changes

Nalgonda technique (option C): It involves the addition of two chemicals (viz. lime and alum) in sequence followed by flocculation, sedimentation and filtration to remove excess fluoride from drinking water.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th edition, page 701

questions.text: Before most surgeries, 1 or 2 doses of antibiotics are given to prevent surgical infections. But in surgeries with a longer operative time, multiple doses may be required. At what frequency are they given intraoperatively in such cases?
questions.solution:
In long operations or when there is excessive blood loss, or when unexpected contamination occurs, antibiotics may be repeated at 4-hourly intervals during the surgery because tissue antibiotic levels often fall faster than serum levels.

Reference: BAILEY AND LOVE :28 TH ED : PG 61

questions.text: A 29 year old female G2P1 presents to an antenatal clinic at 24 weeks for routine check up. USG shows a normal for gestational age fetus at 24 weeks of gestation in frank breech position, with no other abnormalities. What is the most appropriate next step in her management?
questions.solution:
24 weeks gestational age is the ideal time for screening for gestational diabetes therefore, a glucose challenge test with 75 gm of glucose is done.

The patient currently has no other abnormalities. At 24 weeks, breech should not worry you as most of the time it spontaneously rotates and becomes cephalic at term. Thus options C and D are ruled out.

Option B- Culture for genital pathogens is normally done at the initial visit and in certain high risk groups at 32-36 weeks along with group B streptococcal screening.
