questions.text: For diagnosing brain stem death, which of the following tests must be done?
questions.solution:
The cause of irreversible brain stem damage (either from a period of hypoxia, trauma, illness or toxic insult) producing non-responsive coma, must be clearly established.

Following reversible causes must be excluded

  • Intoxication
  • Depressant drugs
  • Muscle relaxants
  • Primary hypothermia
  • Hypovolemic shock
  • Metabolic or endocrine disturbances.

The patient must be examined by a team of doctors at least twice, with a reasonable gap of time in between (say about 6 hours or so).

None of the doctors who participate in the diagnosis of brain-stem death should have any interest in the transplantation of an organ being removed from the cadaver.

The structural and functional damage of brain-stem may be diagnosed depending upon the following observations -

  • Dilated fixed pupils, not responding to sharp changes in intensity of incident light
  • Absence of motor responses within the cranial nerve distribution on painful stimulation
  • Absence of corneal reflexes
  • Absence of vestibulo-ocular reflexes
  • Absence of gag reflex or reflex response to bronchial stimulation by a suction-catheter passed down the trachea
  • Absence of spontaneous breathing (Apnoea test)

Reference: Page 128 33rd edition, THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY by Dr. K.S. Narayan Reddy.

choices.text: Has a bimodal age of presentation
Predominantly has delusion of persecution, reference and grandiosity

questions.text: What is false about paranoid schizophrenia?
questions.solution:
Catatonic and Paranoid subtypes of schizophrenia generally have a good prognosis.

Paranoid Schizophrenia has-

  • More positive symptoms of delusions and hallucinations,
  • Bimodal age of presentation- Maximum in age group of 20-30 followed by late onset psychosis in more than 45 years of age.
  • Responds well to antipsychotics

Reference: Fish's Clinical Psychopathology, 3rd edition

questions.text: A 60 year old male patient, a known case of HTN and DM-II had presented to emergency department with complaint of severe chest pain,palpitation and breathlessness at rest.On ECG Anterior Wall STEMI is present.Patient is thrombolysed with streptokinase.In this patient after thrombolysis we do angiography. What is the goal of reperfusion therapy in the culprit artery?
questions.solution:
When assessed angiographically, flow in the culprit coronary artery is described by a simple qualitative scale called the Thrombolysis in Myocardial Infarction (TIMI) grading system

  • grade 0 indicates complete occlusion of the infarct-related artery
  • grade 1 indicates some penetration of the contrast material beyond the point of obstruction, but without perfusion of the distal coronary bed
  • grade 2 indicates perfusion of the entire infarct vessel into the distal bed, but with flow that is delayed compared with that of a normal artery
  • grade 3 indicates full perfusion of the infarct vessel with normal flow.

TIMI 3 is the goal of reperfusion therapy, because full perfusion of the infarct-related coronary artery yields far better results in terms of limiting infarct size, maintenance of LV function, and reduction of both short- and long-term mortality rates.

Reference: Harrison 21st edition page page 2059

questions.text: A 51 year old male patient has been a chronic bidi smoker since 25 years.His HRCT thorax suggest the diagnosis of Interstitial lung disease.All of the following ILD are associated with the smoking except?
questions.solution:
Although smoking-related ILDs, including respiratory bronchiolitis with interstitial lung disease (RB-ILD), and DIP are frequently subclassified with the IIPs, these disorders (along with PLCH, an ILD with unique clinical, imaging, and histopathologic manifestations) are commonly felt to be the result of active or prior tobacco smoke exposure.

DIP has also been known to occur in children with familial pulmonary fibrosis (FPF). Smokers, particularly elderly smokers, frequently have radiologic (centrilobular) interstitial abnormalities.

These interstitial abnormalities are often incidentally found on routine CXR or chest CT studies in asymptomatic or minimally symptomatic individuals.

Respiratory bronchiolitis is felt to correlate histopathologically with these imaging findings. However, in some cases, these imaging findings can progress to more advanced radiologic changes where more diffuse signs of interstitial pneumonia tend to be present.

Reference: Harrison's 21st edition page no.2194

choices.text: The role of doctor is to ascertain compos mentis
Can be recorded only by the executive magistrate

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding the Dying Declaration?
questions.solution:
The role of a doctor is to certify that the person is conscious and his mental faculties are normal (compos mentis).

Dying Declaration is a written or oral statement of a person, who is dying as a result of some unlawful act, relating to the material facts of cause of his death or bearing on the circumstances. (Section 32, I.E.A.)

Option B : If there is adequate time then the dying declaration is recorded by the executive magistrate. If the condition of the victim is serious, and there is no time to call a Magistrate, the doctor should take the declaration in the presence of two witnesses. The statement can also be recorded by the village headman, police or any other person, but its evidential value will be less.

Option C : Oath is not administered while recording dying declaration, as it is believed that a dying person does not lie.

Option D : Leading questions are not asked in a Dying Declaration. It is recorded in the patient's own words.

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY by Dr. K.S. Narayan Reddy

questions.text: Hemolysis in G6PD enzyme deficiency may occur with all of the following drugs except -
questions.solution: Reference: Harrison 21st edition page 784

questions.text: What is the minimum amount of iodine (in particles per million or ppm) that must be present in iodized salt at the production point and at the consumer level, as per the Prevention of Food Adulteration (PFA) Act?
questions.solution:
In India, the level of iodization is fixed under the Prevention of Food Adulteration (PFA) Act and is not less than 30 ppm at the production point, and not less than 15 ppm of iodine at the consumer level. Iodized salt is the most economical, convenient and effective means of mass prophylaxis in endemic areas. Under the national IDD (Iodine Deficiency Disorders) control activities, the Government of India proposed to completely replace common salt with iodized salt in a phased manner.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th edition, page 700

choices.text: Lacunar infarct of the internal capsule

questions.text: A 75 year old hypertensive man developed an acute onset weakness in his right side involving his arm and leg. On examination he has a right hemiplegia without any sensory loss. Which of the following lesions best explains his deficit?
questions.solution:
Lacunar infarcts are small (2 to 15 mm in diameter) non cortical infarcts caused by occlusion of a single penetrating branch of a large cerebral artery.

The main cerebral branches include the middle cerebral artery, anterior cerebral artery, posterior cerebral artery, basilar artery, and vertebral arteries that supply the cerebrum, cerebellum, and brainstem.

These arteries have deep branches that penetrate and feed deep gray and white matter of the cerebrum, cerebellum, and brainstem. Occlusion or blockage of the small penetrating arteries causes small lacunar strokes. Their size varies from 3 mm to 20 mm in dimension.

Small arterial occlusion is the fundamental pathogenesis for lacunar strokes. The primary underlying pathophysiological process is lipohyalinosis and micro-atheroma formation.

The most common lacunar syndromes are described below -

  • Pure motor hemiparesis - involves the posterior limb of the internal capsule, corona radiata. This type presents with contralateral hemiparesis of the face, arm, and leg. Mild dysarthria may be present with the absence of sensory symptoms. These are the most common lacunar syndromes. They account for 45% of cases of lacunar strokes. Cortical signs like aphasia, cognitive deficit, or visual symptoms are always absent. Pure motor stroke can be a combination of weakness in the arm, leg, or face on one side or any of these parts alone.
  • Ataxic hemiparesis - comprises 10 to 18% of cases. It involves the internal capsule, pons, or corona radiata. It causes hemiparesis of the contralateral face and leg and ataxia of the contralateral limb. Ataxia is the prominent feature of this stroke.
  • Pure sensory stroke - involves the thalamus or corona radiata; it presents with the absent or abnormal sensation of the contralateral of the face, arm, and leg. It accounts for 7% of cases of lacunar strokes. The sensations affected are pain, temperature, touch, pressure, vision, hearing, and taste. A common form of thalamic lacunar stroke is known as Dejerine Roussy syndrome.
  • Dysarthria - clumsy hand syndrome involves the pons or internal capsule and presents with dysarthria and problems pronouncing words due to voice box muscle weakness, including tongue, larynx, and other facial muscle weakness. Contralateral clumsiness of the upper extremity is present with preserved motor strength. There may be difficulty with subtle fine movements such as writing or tying a shoelace.
  • Sensory: motor stroke - involves the thalamus, internal capsule, or putamen-capsule-caudate and presents clinically with a combination of contralateral sensory and motor loss. Sensory-motor lacunar strokes are the second most common type of lacunar strokes. They account for 20% of cases.

Reference: Lacunar Stroke (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK563216/)

questions.text: From 1st January, 2023, an additional dose of which vaccine has been included in the National Immunization Schedule (NIS) of India?
questions.solution:
From 1st January, 2023, a third dose of the f-IPV has been introduced in the NIS, at 9-12 months.


Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th Edition

questions.text: A 14 year old boy presents with complaints of sudden jerky movements of the hands, especially in the morning, leading him to drop objects in his hands for the last few months. His resting EEG is normal. What is the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Myoclonic jerks, especially on awakening and falling of objects from hands suggest a diagnosis of juvenile myoclonic epilepsy.

The myoclonus is precipitated by fatigue, alcohol, sleep deprivation, stress.

The EEG has a characteristic 4-6 Hz bilateral polyspike pattern during the episode, with a normal scan in between attacks.

The cause is usually idiopathic. But brain imaging (MRI) is usually advised to rule out focal pathological causes.

The treatment of choice for JME is valproate. Newer drugs like levetiracetam can also be used as first line drugs.

Reference: Harrison 21st edition page 3400

questions.text: Match the causative agent and the disease -
questions.solution:
1. prowazekii- Epidemic typhus
  2. akari- Rickettsialpox
  3. conorii- Indian tick typhus
  4. rickettsia- Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever (RMSF)

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th Edition, page 326

questions.text: A 20 year old male was started on Trifluoperazine 10 mg, 2 days ago. He presented with complaints of increased muscle tone, abnormal posturing, uprolling of eyes and difficulty in swallowing. How would you treat the patient?
questions.solution:
In the current case scenario the person seems to be suffering from Acute dystonia which is a side effect that develops within hours to days of starting antipsychotic medicines due to sudden blockage of D2 receptors in the nigrostriatal tract.

To overcome this side effect we give centrally acting anticholinergic drugs via IV route for acute management. Drugs commonly used are Benztropine and Promethazine.

Option B - beta blockers are used in the management of akathisia.

Option D - dopamine depleters are used in the management of tardive dyskinesia.

Reference: Fish's Clinical Psychopathology, 3rd edition

questions.text: A multiparous P3L3 young woman who had a normal delivery 3 weeks ago suddenly developed dyspnea with cardiac failure. She has no H/O cardiac disease before and during pregnancy. She had tachycardia and peripheral edema. Her Hb is 9 gm/dl. On 2D ECHO her ejection fraction is 35%.Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Peripartum cardiomyopathy (PPCM) develops during the last trimester or within the first 6 months after pregnancy.

Risk factors are increased maternal age, increased parity, twin pregnancy, malnutrition, use of tocolytic therapy for premature labor, and preeclampsia or toxemia of pregnancy.

Several of these risk factors contribute to antiangiogenic signaling through secreted vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) inhibitors, such as soluble FLT1 (sFLT1).

Another recently proposed mechanism invokes an abnormal prolactin cleavage fragment, which is induced by oxidative stress and also affects angiogenesis; this observation has led to preliminary investigation of bromocriptine as possible therapy.

As the increased circulatory demand of pregnancy can aggravate other cardiac disease that was clinically unrecognized, it is crucial to the diagnosis of PPCM that there be no evidence for a preexisting cardiac disorder.

By contrast, heart failure presenting earlier in pregnancy has been termed pregnancy-associated cardiomyopathy (PACM).

As in familial and sporadic DCM, truncating mutations, predominantly in TTN, are present in 15% of patients with PPCM and are associated with systolic dysfunction that persists. Pregnancy may represent another example of environmental triggers for accelerated phenotypic expression of genetic cardiomyopathies.

Option A - ACUTE MI is less likely as in question there is no chest pain, no ECG changes, and no cardiac biomarker mentioned.

Option B - DVT with PE is less likely because in PE 2D ECHO shows RV dyskinesia with or without tricuspid regurgitation.

Option C - Amniotic Fluid Embolism ruled out as it occurs immediately during active labor.

Reference: Harrison 21st edition page page 1963

choices.text: Better than or equal to 3/60 but worse than 6/60
Better than or equal to 6/60 but worse than 6/18
Better than or equal to 6/18 but worse than 6/12

questions.text: How is moderate vision impairment for distance defined?
questions.solution:
Distance vision impairment:

  • Mild - Presenting visual acuity worse than 6/12
  • Moderate - Presenting visual acuity worse than 6/18
  • Severe - Presenting visual acuity worse than 6/60
  • Blindness - Presenting visual acuity worse than 3/60

Near vision impairment

Presenting near vision acuity worse than N6 or N8 at 40 cm with existing correction.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th Edition, page 430

questions.text: You admit a 19-year-old with acute-onset heart failure and left ventricular dysfunction. After assessment, you suspect acute viral myocarditis, which is confirmed on endomyocardial biopsy. Which of the following therapies is recommended for treatment for acute viral myocarditis?
questions.solution:
There is currently no specific therapy recommended during any stage of viral myocarditis.

During acute infection, therapy with anti-inflammatory or immunosuppressive medications is avoided, as their use has been shown to increase viral replication and myocardial injury in animal models.

Therapy with specific antiviral agents (such as oseltamivir) has not been studied in relation to cardiac involvement.

There is ongoing investigation into the impact of antiviral therapy to treat chronic viral persistence identified from endomyocardial biopsy.

Large trials of immunosuppressive therapy for Dallas Criteria-positive myocarditis have been negative. There are some initial encouraging results and ongoing investigations with immunosuppressive therapy for immune-mediated myocarditis defined by immuno histologic criteria on biopsy or circulating anti-heart antibodies in the absence of myocardial viral genomes

However, neither antiviral nor anti-inflammatory therapies are currently recommended.

Until there is a better understanding of the phases of viral myocarditis and the effects of targeted therapies, treatment will continue to be guided by general recommendations for dilated cardiomyopathy, which includes angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors (ACEIs).

Reference: Harrison 21st edition page 1961

questions.text: The 'rule of halves' applies to which disease?
questions.solution:
Hypertension is an 'iceberg' disease. It became evident in the early 1970s that only about half of the hypertensive subjects in the general population of most developed countries were aware of the condition, only about half of those aware of the problem were being treated, and only about half of those treated were considered adequately treated.



The areas of the circles shown in the figure correspond to the actual proportions observed in several population based studies and number-wise represent the following :

  1. The whole community
  2. Normotensive subjects
  3. Hypertensive subjects
  4. Undiagnosed hypertension
  5. Diagnosed hypertension
  6. Diagnosed but untreated
  7. Diagnosed and treated
  8. Inadequately treated
  9. Adequately treated

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th Edition, page 404

choices.text: Vertigo lasting for days after a URTI

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding vestibular neuronitis is false?
questions.solution:
Proposed etiologies -

  • Viral infection
  • Vascular occlusion Immunologic mechanisms.

Clinical features -

  • Sudden onset of vertigo with nausea and vomiting
  • Vertigo lasting days after an upper respiratory infection.
  • No hearing loss
  • No other neurologic sign or symptoms
  • The patient may have postural instability toward the injured ear but is still able to walk without falling.
  • The patient usually does not have a headache.
  • Spontaneous nystagmus characteristic of an acute peripheral vestibular injury.

Treatment -

  • Symptomatic and supportive care during the acute phase of the illness.
  • Vestibular suppressants
  • Antiemetics

Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, P L Dhingra, 8th edition

choices.text: Copper deficiency can cause similar symptoms
Dorsal column and lateral tracts are involved
All cases of neurological impairment show macrocytosis

questions.text: All of the following are true about Subacute combined demyelination of spinal cord, except -
questions.solution:
Copper is absorbed in the stomach and duodenum. It plays an important role in methylation reactions that are utilized in the formation of myelin protein.

Deficiency of myelin due to vitamin B12 or copper will affect heavily myelinated tracts like posterior and lateral columns of the spinal cord causing loss of proprioception.

B12 supplementation is required initially parenterally, but later orally for the entire lifetime of this patient.

Neurological manifestations can occur alone and can precede the development of anemia.

Reference: Harrison 21st edition page 3454

questions.text: Bilateral down sloping graph with high frequency hearing loss on PTA is characteristic of -
questions.solution:
Presbycusis refers to bilateral age-related hearing loss. In literal terms, presbycusis means 'old hearing' or 'elder hearing '. It is the most common cause of hearing loss worldwide. The hallmark of presbycusis is the impaired ability to understand high-frequency components of speech (voiceless consonants, such as p, k, f, s, and ch)

Pure tone audiometry is performed to assess the degree of hearing loss and the results are presented in the form of an audiogram. In presbycusis, the highest frequency sounds are typically affected first, followed by lower and lower frequency sounds as the condition progresses. Presbycusis is characterized by bilateral hearing loss above 2000 Hertz. On a standard audiogram, presbycusis appears as an overall down-sloping line that represents impaired hearing at higher frequency sounds.

Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, P L Dhingra, 8th edition

choices.text: Recheck BP third time as error

questions.text: A 40 year old female has a BP of 130/100 mmHg on two separate occasions. Her father is also hypertensive and is on medication. Blood investigations are within normal range. What is the next step in her management?
questions.solution:
Reduction of diastolic BP to less than 60-80 mmHg does not improve mortality and may lead to adverse cardiovascular events.

This is called the J curve phenomenon.

Considering her positive family history, dietary approaches to stop hypertension is the best possible way.



Causes of isolated diastolic hypertension -

  • Essential hypertension
  • Hypothyroidism
  • Conn syndrome
  • Cushing syndrome

Reference: Harrison 21st edition page page 2082

questions.text: A 40 year old female patient had a complaint of fatigue, dry skin, irregular menses and weight gain presented to you. You suspect hypothyroidism. Her TSH level is elevated and T4 is normal but the Anti-TPO antibody is positive .What is the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
The patient's symptoms suggest primary hypothyroidism.

Adult patients under 60 years old without evidence of heart disease may be started on 50-100 μg of LT4 daily. The dose is adjusted on the basis of TSH levels, with the goal of treatment being a normal TSH, ideally in the lower half of the reference range.

TSH responses are gradual and should be measured about 2 months after instituting treatment or after any subsequent change in LT4 dosage. The clinical effects of LT4 replacement are slow to appear.

Patients may not experience full relief from symptoms until 3-6 months after normal TSH levels are restored. Adjustment of LT4 dosage is made in 12.5- or 25-μg increments if the TSH is high; decrements of the same magnitude should be made if the TSH is suppressed.



Carbimazole and propranolol are used in treatment of hyperthyroidism.

Reference: Harrison 21st edition page 2936
